That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the House on 5 December last year, I responded to a statement by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) at the tabling of the government's response to the recommendations of the aviation safety inquiry report. In his response and statement, the minister said that he planned to give a further reference to the committee's successor, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform, in the coming year. That has not occurred. There has been no further reference. I ask the minister: when will he give that further reference to the committee? I express my serious disappointment at the failure of the government to respond to the recommendations of the Plane safe report. He responded in words, but not with action. There were many expectations raised in the recommendations of that report but they have not been carried out in practice. I will go through them one by one.

SPEECH.PARA: A major recommendation of the committee's report was that there would be a publication on a monthly basis of serious safety deficiencies identified in charter aircraft. Those reports have not been published despite the government's response of 5 December 1996 which stated that the report would be published monthly and that the first serious deficiency report would be published to cover the calendar month of January 1997. It is now September 1997. The first report is yet to be published. We had anticipated that the first report would be published in March 1996. The change in government altered that. It has taken the new government nine months to respond to recommendations that had already been responded to by the previous government.

Added to that we now get into September 1997 and still there is no publication of any serious safety deficiency report in respect of charter aircraft. This is the most serious area of poor administration and performance in the whole aviation system. It is quite clear here that the industry and some of the players within the industry have managed to forestall the publication of this information. When we made a recommendation in the Ships of shame report in December 1992 that information should be published on the owners of ships that were detained, the nature of the deficiency of the ship, the reasons for unseaworthiness, the charterers and all parties associated with that vessel, there were cries of heresy and alarm and claims about the damage it would do to the industry all around the world. Those reports are now published on a monthly basis across the world. Other countries, such as some in Europe, as well as the European Commission and the United States Coastguard, publish much more extensive sets of information on those ships than we originally recommended.

Similarly I deplore the failure of the government to publish that information on aviation. That is the immediate discipline that is available to the community so people can know which firms are not meeting aviation safety requirements. It seems to me that since the change in government, despite all the rhetoric about aviation safety, the lid has been slammed shut on information being available to the community.

In the same speech the minister referred to the code of conduct in relation to the domestic code‐share flights, and the fact that tickets from Qantas and Ansett would incorporate printed information advising of a code‐share service being operated and giving the name of the carrier operating the service. All other tickets being issued by travel agents would have a sticker advising the consumer if it was a code‐share flight. That has not occurred. That information is not being provided to the public. It ought to be provided. The public are entitled to know.

There are 41 million passengers who travel by air in Australian airspace each year. Those people are entitled to know. Now we see a move by Airservices Australia, supported by certain vested interests, to change arrangements in respect of airspace where, it is said, there is a $20 million per year saving to be made by changing the existing arrangements. And we see the professionals in aviation, the pilots who are flying regular public transport aircraft, opposing the proposal in respect of class E airspace.

The cost of those arrangements is one cent per week per passenger. This passenger is very happy to see that paid to ensure that those arrangements in respect of class E airspace continue. But it is another example of how certain vested interests in this country are not allowing activities and discipline to take place that should occur in respect of aviation safety .
Let me go then to my questions, numbers 1093, 1094 and 1095 to the minister on 12 December 1996, when I asked:
Is he able to give an assurance that individual Qantas domestic aircraft are not operating on continuing scheduled flights each month with a higher number of safety defects than 1994?

Question number 1093 asked a similar question in respect of Ansett, and question 1095 asked another similar question in respect of any other activities. On February 1997 I received answers to those questions. They came back with the same answer which stated:

The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has advised that the Authority can not supply details of the relative number of defects which may be carried on individual Ansett aircraft. To determine the number of such defects would require an examination and subsequent assessment of every entry made in each aircraft's technical log book since 1993. CASA does not have the resources to carry out such an examination without severely compromising its ability to perform its regular surveillance functions.

That is nonsense, Mr Deputy Speaker. The information I sought is carried on the maintenance release sheets of those aircraft. The airlines themselves have that information. They need to have that information on a regular basis—flight by flight, day by day, week by week, month by month—to supervise the safe operation of their own aircraft. That information is available. All that is happening here is `bang' the lid has slammed shut. They do not want that information to get out.

Passengers are entitled to that information to make good decisions about whom they want to travel with. It is an immediate discipline upon operators to ensure they are doing the right thing. I would not have asked those questions if I had not had reason to ask them, and the reason I had to ask them was that information had been provided to me that there had been a change on the part of airline managements to allow a higher number of safety related defects to go unrepaired in the operation of commercial aircraft.

There are a number of quite legitimate things that you can do. There is what we call minimum equipment listing. The answer that came back from the minister could have said, `We will do some part of it,' or, `There is a minimum equipment listing that could have explained some nature of it.' Some information could have been provided without any difficulty at all.

But remember, this is not coming from the authority. This is not the Civil Aviation Safety Authority that signs off on these answers. The minister of the Crown signs off on these answers. This is a government answer, not an authority answer. The authority prepares the information, but it is the government that signs off. So that lid has slammed shut.

To get around that, I went back to the minister with a similar question in February of this year. But I thought, `I will confine it to just one month and they can't say they haven't got the resources for one month.' I asked the same question with respect to December 1996:
How many (a) written and (b) other expressions of concern about the safe operation of air services did his Department or any other agency for which he is responsible receive in December 1996.
Back came the answer six months later. Note the time. It took six months to get this paltry answer from information that was readily available. The answer stated:

In December 1996, BASI received a total of five written reports via its Confidential Aviation Incident Reporting system; CASA received 6 written expressions of concern; and Airservices received 128 written reports of concern.
That is for one month only. The information is readily categorised, but I draw the attention of honourable members to the nature of the complaints in that answer. That is:
All five written reports received by BASI . . . were related to regular public transport (RPT) operations.
The RPT carry the 41 million passengers per year that I referred to a few minutes ago. One of the complaints was the:
. . . failure by pilots of non‐passenger carrying flights to respond to RPT aircraft transmissions in mandatory broadcast zones—

This goes to the safe operation of air space because, when it was mandatory for another aircraft to respond to an RPT aircraft transmission, it did not happen. But we would not have been told that if we had not pursued the questions.

The second complaint was about the safe stowage of walking sticks in aircraft cabins. That could have been about staff. The third was about checking fuel quantity. That is important. The fifth one was an:
. . . allegation of substitution of Class B aircraft*—
which are non‐RPT aircraft that operate at a lower set of safety standards than regular public transport aircraft—
for Class A aircraft* to operate RPT services.

That is exactly what happened in the Seaview Air disaster. Aircraft that were not certificated to operate as regular public transport aircraft—they were class B charter aircraft with a lower set of standards—were substituted to perform the task of class A aircraft. That was the fifth complaint that came out.
Then there were the six written reports of concern that were made to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. What was the first one? It was:
Allegation of substitution of Class B aircraft* for Class A aircraft*
The second:
Recommendation for a special audit of an operator
The third:
Low flying aircraft over Cable Beach, WA
That was for charter aircraft. The fourth:
Operator maintenance and flight crew duty times
That was also for charter aircraft. The fifth:
Upper torso restraint requirements for passengers
That was for RPT. The last:
Standard instrument departure, non‐compliance
That was for high capacity regular public transport aircraft. That is a serious matter. But we had to drag this out—it is like extracting teeth—of the minister and the government.

Then there are the oral expressions of concern. There was an alleged dive bombing of a shopping centre by a charter aircraft. There was a question on the safety of an operator, given the media attention on aviation safety: RPT. A low flying aircraft over Kuranda was RPT. There was an observation that a float plane operating over a populated area was flying the wrong way in an aircraft lane of entry—that was charter aircraft and regular public transport aircraft—and then there was a low flying aircraft on approach to Perth Airport. But then the answer goes on to say that there were 128 different reports, mostly from pilots, to Airservices Australia itself.

I am deeply disappointed that that information is not readily available. I am more disappointed, and worried, that the safety deficiency reports have not been published. I call on the minister and the government to ensure that those reports are published as quickly as possible. I will not accept the feeble excuse that there is now some legal obstacle to that—that there may be some suit for damages or defamation if information were to be published. We went through that questioning and checking process during our committee hearing into the Civil Aviation Safety Authority legislation back in May 1996.

Questions 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018, which I first asked on 26 June and which remain unanswered at this date, all go to asking for specific responses from the minister on what periodic reports have been produced. What has been the substance of each monthly report he has received from the program advisory panel? What reports have been published on safety deficiencies detected by CASA in its normal work? The answer to that is none, but it does not take three months to tell me none. Then the code share flight information: has that been published? No, it has not. I also asked him whether the safety pamphlet he referred to in his speech on 5 December 1996 would be circulated widely. That has not happened, and I still have no answer.

I asked for answers and information on each of those matters that came out of his statement and came out of the committee's report. That report, as I said, has had the lid slammed shut on it. There has been a lot of talk. There has been a lot of rhetoric, but the passengers—those 41 million people who travel in Australian airspace each year—are entitled to the best level of safety than we can give them. The mechanisms are there, but there is no reportage taking place and the public is not being informed.

I conclude with the answer the minister gave me on question 1569, which came back on 5 August 1997, in respect of Robinson R22 helicopters. Again I refuse to accept that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority believes that the use of unapproved or bogus aircraft parts is of virtually nil importance in this country. I do not have time to go into the details of the answer—they are there in answer to the question in Hansard—but I refuse to accept that and I will pursue it further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marek, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I take the opportunity to speak in relation to the Plane safe report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. Many members may know that I am a pilot of approximately 1,000 hours experience. I am endorsed on several different aircraft, and I own my own twin‐engine 310 aircraft, which I have had for approximately eight years. I have got my own maintenance facility, fully approved and registered by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, so I feel that I can talk with some authority, particularly in relation to aviation safety.

SPEECH.PARA: With various committees, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has looked very closely into aviation safety in this country. It is apparent that the aviation industry in this country has been lacking leadership and control for far too long. Aviation inspectors have never had the teeth to be able to deliver safety in this country as it should be delivered. The minister has discussed this in depth in his ministerial statement in relation to the Monarch and the Seaview accidents.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure inquiry that has now been completed produced the Plane safe report. I must say the committee has done a very good job going into aviation safety and looking at various aspects, but one thing that I could point out is that the aviation industry is unique in its own way. Unless people know the industry very well, they may not know what questions to ask, and the opportunity to ask them probably would not happen.

If we are going to have people in the country who are looking closely into aviation safety, then maybe we should have people who are experienced in the industry involved with those committees. I am more than sure that they have seen things that have happened in the past which need to be brought to attention. If those people have never been involved in the industry—if they have never flown or been closely involved with it—then I can understand that some of the questions that need to be asked probably would not be asked.

One of the particular problems in past years has been that people have not been game, if that is the right way of putting it, to front the Civil Aviation Safety Authority—or the then Bureau of Air Safety Investigation—for it was always seen as being somewhat like the Gestapo. If people had a problem or they were not sure about a particular issue, they were genuinely concerned that if they brought the issue to attention they might find themselves in trouble.

A lot of people I know went out of their way, if they saw an incident or if there was something that was not right, to make sure that they kept their mouth shut and their head down; they basically flushed over it. They did not want to draw attention to themselves. The industry under the Labor government, particularly with the member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton) at the wheel, always appeared as a real mates' industry and, depending on who you were, that might have been be right. That was just a perception, I guess, but it was one that was out there. Whether it was right or not is for individuals to decide.

I am more than sure that the industry has had many problems for many years which should have been fixed up a long time ago, but obviously they never have been. The Keating government, and the Labor governments of the previous 13 years, had the opportunity to do something about it. Now we hear Labor talk in a very hairy‐chested way about the fact that this government should be doing something about it. Well, we are. Labor had 13 years of government to get involved and fix the industry and now they are blaming us. Now, 13 months from when all this came about, people are saying we should have done something. They say 13 years for Labor and 13 months for the coalition government—I do not really think it rings true. We are doing the best we can. I must say, though, that in the standing committees both Labor and the coalition are working well together, but when people want to throw mud, they should have a look in their own backyard first.

As far as people travelling in charter aircraft are concerned, I am a great believer that if you are a commuter—a member of the general public—you need to have a greater awareness of your rights when using the aviation industry.If people are not sure about the flight they are about to take, if they are not really keen on the aircraft because it may not look that good, or if they have something like a gut feeling that makes them feel that something is not right, they should ask the pilot. If it is a light charter aircraft usually there will be, as well as yourself, six to 10 others, the pilot and maybe a stewardess or assistant. It does not hurt; there is no problem with asking. That is a great problem with the general public. People do not understand or do not know their rights in relation to air travel. We are all responsible for our own safety.

I say to people, one and all, if you are about to travel on a light aircraft charter, regular public transport or a private flight, if there is something you are not sure about, ask the pilot. You never know, you might find out that something is amiss and you may be helping yourself and your fellow passengers.

I know when I jump on a private aircraft or when I am being transported around the country on charter aircraft I usually have a quick look around the aircraft myself. There is nothing wrong with that. You do not have to touch anything; you just have to have a bit of a look around and see whether the plane looks all right. Quite a lot of pilots do that. They take an extreme interest in other people's aircraft. In an aeroplane, there is a place for everything and everything in its place. If something is not right or something is not neat and tidy you can usually tell with the naked eye.

Another thing I wish to bring into the discussion today is where the industry has gone in the short time that Minister Sharp has had an opportunity to do something with it. There is a different perception floating around in the community. People are starting to become more au fait, more comfortable, with dealing with safety investigators. They are not perceived as the Gestapo any more. They are starting to be seen as a group of individuals who are trying to do something for the industry.

If you are a pilot or are involved in the aviation industry and you make a valid, genuine mistake, then there is no reason why you should not be able to approach the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and talk to them. The industry should know that if it is not sure about something it should ask. They cannot throw you into gaol for that. It was a perception that people had in years past that if you put your head up you might get it knocked off.

One thing in particular that the industry has developed and which has come a long way is the bulletin produced by the aviation industry through CASA. It is the Airservices Bulletin. It is good reading material for pilots. It gives a bit of an indication of what is going on in the industry at present, and it brings the investigators, the bureaucracy, of the industry closer to the people. I think that that is absolutely important.

BREAK.PARA: In the bulletin are electronic safety incident reports, and I will allude to one of them. The executive summary reads:
A Piper PA28—
That is a single engine light aircraft—
was on a zone flight in the Sydney zone and identified an aircraft which flew into his path as a Lancair.
A Piper PA28 was on a zone flight from Hornsby to the Harbour Bridge at 1500' when the radar controller noticed a primary paint on a north‐easterly heading well in the control zone.
Obviously the controller was looking at his screen as the radar was painting the picture of what was in the air at the time, and he identified this aircraft. It continues:
Traffic was passed and the Piper confirmed he had a white Lancair in sight in the 0230 position. The Piper stated the altitude of the Lancair was 1300'.
As we can see, there was a 200 feet difference between the two aircraft—that is how it appeared by sight. It went on to say:

The radar paints merged as the aircraft passed over each other. When questioned by Flight Service, the Lancair pilot mentioned he had flown close to a Piper Cherokee and believed he should have had right of way. The Lancair was unaware he had flown through the Sydney control zone.

The industry needs to update itself. We see this need coming very shortly with Airspace 2000. There is a perception out there at the moment that Airspace 2000 is going to cause people and pilots heartache, that it is going to make industry unsafe. This is the furthest thing from the truth.

Airspace 2000 is aircraft that will be flying around in various parts of the country, particularly between the altitudes of 4,500 feet to 8,000‐odd feet. It is mandatory that they carry charlie‐mode transponders. The idea is that aircraft which travel with these transponders will be able to be seen on a radar. It is as simple as that. People will know their exact position, their altitude, where they are going and where they are coming from. It is about time the industry got up to date and installed these things and had them in operation in aircraft as soon as possible.

Another thing the industry could do to update itself—particularly for private pilots; they mostly seem to be the ones who are coming somewhat unstuck—is to have global positioning systems. You can purchase most GPSs for around the $1,000 to $1,500 mark these days. They have moving map displays which show your aircraft the track where it is going—from one point relative to the other—and it also shows the airspace and whether you are going to invade that airspace or not.

If pilots had an opportunity to use GPS, then it would be of great benefit to all. Not only would it stop some people being unaware of their positions and getting lost and costing the industry a lot of money, but also it would help people to locate themselves throughout the country so that they do not get into controlled airspace that they should not be in.

The problem at the moment is that within the aviation industry you are not allowed to use something that is not a recognised and approved instrument or that is not TSO'd or whatever. What we need to do is have a closer look at this and make the industry and the systems more user friendly. The instrument may not have the ability to be interrogated by itself. We have various aviation GPSs and they cost up to $10,000. I have one in my aircraft. It is TSO'd, but it is only for VFR flight and cost about $5,000. If people had the opportunity to use GPSs and the industry accepted them all, we would be a lot better off because people would carry them whereas at the moment it is not accepted as fair and equitable.

I would like the aviation industry in Australia to have a closer look at the use of GPS. Fair enough, it may not be an approved GPS, but I am telling you right here and now it would go a long way towards making the industry safer; it would stop people from encroaching on airspace that they should not be in, and it would also go a long way towards helping people who may get lost.

In closing, as far as I am concerned the coalition government is doing its best. With the cooperation of the Labor opposition, maybe we will have an opportunity to really redevelop our aviation industry in this country. It is an industry that has been brought to its knees over recent years. A lot of pilots have had to sell their aircraft. They cannot afford to be in the industry any longer. It has become far too expensive. That is another great problem. People try to look at appropriate safety in relation to the expense. We need to have a change in thinking in the industry, a change in focus in the industry and, hopefully, with all that in mind, it will become a better industry for all.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 August, on motion by Mr Reith.
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, let me firstly congratulate you for being appointed to that position. Welcome to the club. Let me also assure you that it will be the hardest $28 a month you will ever earn in this parliament. Nevertheless, I wish you well in the position.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to be able to make a short contribution to this debate on Ships of shame—a sequel. You might ask, `What is the condition of ships in Australian waters today?' Before we answer that we have to separate the types of ships in the Australian waters. Australian flagged and crewed ships, in general, and especially the larger ones, are in very good condition. However, I had an unfortunate incident in my area last year when a coastal vessel went aground at Bass Point. It was found out later that there were lots of questions about the condition of that ship. But, in general, the Australian flagged and crewed ships around the Australian coastline are in quite good condition.

Then we come to the condition of ships that are flagged and crewed from overseas. Despite the report of Ships of shame—a sequel and the publicity that the report has received, in general the condition of these ships has not greatly improved. I note from the Daily Commercial News that on average about 10 or 12 ships are detained each month for a variety of defects. Some of these are only minor defects, but some ships are detained for quite serious defects.

It is true that the general public and, indeed, the trade are more aware of the conditions of ships. I am a great supporter of AMSA. I think they are doing a good job and that they are carrying out more inspections now than they were a few years ago. But nothing that I have seen shows any great improvement in the condition of ships. Because of this, there are a couple of basic facts that we have to consider.

BREAK.PARA: The world's shipping fleet is ageing—there is absolutely no doubt about that. We have not been replacing ships, and maybe that is because it is too expensive. I have long argued that we should have a ship construction industry here in Australia. When people talk to me about cost, the labour costs in Korea and Japan are as high as ours today and a few years ago I saw a ship construction works in Denmark where their wages were as high as those in Australia. By using modern technology, we could have a ship building industry here and we should also have a ship repair facility along the east coast of Australia.

As I have said, the world's fleet is ageing and the trade is becoming increasingly competitive. It seems to me that, in a competitive environment, we should be looking at well maintained ships, properly trained crews and properly paid and fed crews. Exactly the reverse is what we have got. We have poor ships, with often appalling conditions and poorly trained crews, and multi‐crewed as a method of controlling the crew. There will be half a dozen different languages spoken among the crew. They will be poorly paid, if they are paid at all, and poorly fed. That is the condition of many, many ships along the Australian coast today.

My reports, especially with regard to Port Kembla, are that we still see these poor ships coming in there. I wonder if this would still happen if these ships were crewed not by Third World countries but by nationals of other countries. Many of the Third World crew are in a form of bondage. We like to think slavery ended over 100 years ago, but I sometimes wonder when I see the conditions that these crews have to endure on these ships. If it were not for the Missions to Seamen and, indeed, the International Transport Federation, the conditions would be even worse.

But a price is paid when people contact the ITF—the International Transport Federation. There have been cases of bashings and of black‐listing. The black list still exists for those crews who approach the unions about getting their proper pay; they are black‐listed and never work again on a seagoing vessel. With many people when they are in Australian ports—and I have had personal experience of this—the captain pays them the amount while they are here to get them out of the Australian port and when they are out of the port that money is taken back off them. This happens time and time again. Indeed, what also often happens—and I had occasion to mention this in the House last night—is that seafarers disappear off the Australian coastline. We say nothing about it.

If someone fell out of a plane, we most certainly would hear about that. I remember recently that a plane was coming from Fiji or somewhere and someone fell out of it. We have just had a debate on aviation safety and we all get terribly concerned about that. But often when a crew member has complained about conditions on a ship or has made contact with the ITF representative in one of the Australian ports, if they are sailing from Fremantle across to Adelaide or Melbourne they do not make it—their grave is the Great Australian Bight; or if they made contact with the ITF representative in Port Kembla or Sydney and their ship is going on to Brisbane, Mackay, or somewhere north, their grave is off the east coast of Australia—a very watery grave. This happens.

Some people ought to start asking a few questions about how many foreign seafarers go overboard off the coast of Australia. Quite frankly, it would astonish you if you knew the number of seafarers who go missing off the coast of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And no press reports?

—No press. The press is not interested. If a light plane went down in Denmark or Finland and three people were killed, it would make page 2 of the Sydney Morning Herald or the Daily Telegraph . If there was an Australian on it, it would make page 1. We had 185 seafarers go down off the coast of Western Australia in an 18‐month period and no media in Australia thought that important enough to report. You are right about that.

BREAK.PARA: What we are also finding increasingly is shonky foreign operators using the Australian legal system and the Australian courts to protect their evil ways. We have 45D, unfortunately, on the legislation books in Australia. Some of the few people using that disgraceful piece of legislation are lawyers acting for shonky shipping owners out of London, or slick and sleazy ones, as the industry knows, out of Greece.

We have a case at the moment, which the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) has highlighted before in this parliament, about the MV Hunter. Australian lawyers, who should be ashamed of themselves, are using Australian laws to protect shonky overseas owners who are discriminating against and mistreating foreign crews. Australian lawyers who are doing that by using 45D should be ashamed of themselves. They bring no credit to their profession at all.

The whole question of shipping today and the condition of crews more and more are becoming an industrial relations issue in Australia and in Australian courts—because undoubtedly it is going to tie up our courts as well. Shonky foreign owners, as I was saying, are increasingly using Australian courts and the Australian legal profession, and this government is doing absolutely nothing about it. It is giving passive support to what these lawyers are doing in using the Australian legal system to protect shonky overseas owners and to disadvantage their crews, who are often from Third World countries.

We would not tolerate what goes on in ships if it happened on the buses plying around Australia. When you and I fly business class—we do not fly first class any more—if we had a half‐starved steward serving us our meal or a drink we would be ashamed. If we saw the bruises on them where they had been bashed, or if the captain occasionally left the cockpit and gave it over to the pilot and took an iron bar—as a captain did in Port Hedland—and beat one of the crew on the aircraft that we were flying on, we would be a little concerned.

We might even get up in this parliament and make a speech about it. We would say that that was not the Australian way of dealing with our employees or our crew. If it does not happen on buses or aircraft, why do we turn a blind eye when such things happen on shipping?

I do have genuine concerns about doing away with cabotage, about opening our coastal runs. People say to me it will bring down the rates—I am not quite sure it will bring down the rates—and if the rates become so low jobs will most definitely be taken away from the railway.

We have heard a lot in this parliament and in the media about the bribe—or whatever you might like to call it—during the recent Northern Territory election, when the federal government kicked in $100 million for the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line. We were told that this was going to bring down freight costs and that ships were going to come to Darwin with containers and rail would bring them down here.

The government cannot have it both ways. They are talking about opening the Australian coastline and that will bring the cost down as well. You cannot have it both ways. If you bring the cost of the coastal shipping down that low through having rust buckets and Third World, poorly paid crews on them, your economic argument for the Alice Springs to Darwin railway will not stand up. If it is going to be as cheap—as you are all saying—along the coast, why build the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line when it would be so much cheaper just to leave it all on the ships to come around?

I said before that I was generally satisfied with the condition of ships—Australian crewed and Australian flagged—but I do have a concern about some of the cattle ships, especially those out of Darwin. I do not want to say anything here that would jeopardise that trade because I support that trade but I think we have to give a bit of attention to the condition of some of those ships and the conditions for some of the crews.

Mr Deputy Speaker, even if you do not agree with it, you would appreciate that there is a manic determination—I will not say who has got it—to destroy the Maritime Union of Australia. There is an ideological hatred by certain sections of this parliament of the MTU. Let me say that it has been tried before: people have tried to destroy the Maritime Union of Australia. The old troops have been threatened. But it will not work. My members and I will fight and we will resist this. So forget that manic determination.

People today are more aware of the conditions of shipping but do they care? I suggest to honourable members, and I do this genuinely, that they visit the Mission to Seamen in their city and talk to the crews. Even if members do not represent a port, most of the ports around Australia have a Mission to Seamen facility. Foreign crews might not always be able to talk because they might be frightened to talk or they might have difficulties with the language but members can talk to the chaplain at any Mission to Seamen around the Australian coastline. Let me tell you that the stories that they will tell you will horrify you. Then ask yourselves, is this what we want in Australia? Is this what we want for Australian workers?

We hear much about the level playing field. There is nothing level about this playing field—if we can use that term with regard to shipping—introducing rust buckets of the world to the Australian coastal run, crewed by underpaid, abused seafarers, often from Third World countries. It is un‐Australian and we should not tolerate it for one moment.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ted Grace) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Mr Taylor:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I have to put another hat on now and speak briefly on the report on Australia's relations with southern Africa. It was my privilege, when this committee was first established in the last parliament, to chair this committee. We had completed most of the work when the election was called. When the new parliament was formed, and the committee was formed again, the bringing down of the report came under the Foreign Affairs Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a lot of suggestions about what we should look at. As a committee of this parliament looking at sub‐Saharan Africa, we found it such a diverse, huge and complex area that we had some difficulty focusing on exactly what we should be looking at. Basically, we wanted to look at the impact of the democratic South Africa on post‐apartheid Africa. There had been genuine elections and there was majority rule in South Africa, which was playing its part, and we wanted to look at the impact of that, and so we settled on the SADC countries to focus our attention on.

It is true to say that most of the evidence that we received and most of the witnesses that came before us were either from South Africa or Zimbabwe. After Mauritius joined SADC we also had some very important input from that state. We did receive some written submissions from some of the other countries, but there was not the same input from the other SADC countries that there had been from South Africa and Zimbabwe.

The real worry that many people expressed was that South Africa, because of its economic and trading strength, would dominate the region to an extent, and there has been debate about whether there should be free trade between the areas or not. It is true and, I guess, inevitable that South Africa would play a very dominant role in that part of the world. It is of concern that we in Australia do not put the emphasis that I feel we should on the whole of southern Africa.

It always seems to me that in this country we can only manage to focus on one country at a time. A few years ago, it was all China. Everything was for China: we were doing reports in China, trade delegations were going there and trade delegations were coming here. We often do that at the expense of other countries. It is the same with the rest of Asia. I am one of the keenest supporters of the idea, and I actually do fundamentally believe, that our future and our destiny lie with Asia.

Nevertheless, having said that, we should not forget our traditional markets and our contacts with European countries—and, indeed, Africa. We should not. Africa is not easy; it is difficult. And in many cases we are in a competitive situation, especially with South Africa, not only on the sporting field but also in the trading field. We have the question of our wine. South Africa rightly tries to expand its wine market throughout Europe but this is going to impact on Australian wine sales unless we lift our game and make sure that it does not. The same goes for coal and a whole range of things that South Africa deals in.

Everyone tells me these are very difficult economic times, but I think that some of our missions there could do with an increase in staff. For instance, it is quite silly having the high commissioner to Zimbabwe representing seven or eight countries. I recently was speaking to someone who has been appointed high commissioner to Nigeria and I said, `You are going to Nigeria: what other countries are you going to be accredited to?' And he listed all the other countries.

I know that we have discussed this in other forums, but one thing I have always felt is that we did not achieve what we wanted to with a position on the Security Council in the United Nations ballot last year, because we had largely ignored Africa diplomatically. I know we sent our high commissioners around Africa to do a little bit of lobbying, but there is no substitute for having someone there. For example, Namibia is a country where I feel we should have a high commissioner.

My personal view is only a feeling I have—and I have nothing to substantiate it—that we should have put more effort into the African continent and, over the past few years, not cut down on our representation throughout Africa so that we now have not got anyone at all to represent us in francophone Africa. They have a huge voting block in the United Nations, but what have we got? We have a high commission in Kenya, one in South Africa and one in Zimbabwe. I led a famous delegation through Africa a few years back—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about it.

—Well, you can read about it. One of the recommendations that we made was to reopen a post in Ethiopia at Addis Ababa, as a previous delegation had recommended three years before. We went to Addis Ababa. That post was opened for two or three years. The Canadians came in and bought everything at bargain basement prices. When we got there, after two years, it had closed down. Ethiopia is the headquarters of the Organisation of African Unity. It is represented by the High Commissioner to Kenya. At that time, I argued that we should have it even as a listening post. Our report suggested that we should reopen that post in Addis. The general public were more interested in other parts of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: We have made a whole host of recommendations in connection with Australia's relations with southern Africa. It is an important area for Australia, and it is going to be increasingly important to us. Too often in the past, we have treated southern Africa far too casually, as we have so many other countries. It is very rare for even a parliamentary delegation to go there. I know they are not the flavour of the month at the moment. We tend to take it so much for granted.

The other point about southern Africa is that they are much better represented in Australia. You have to look at the countries that have high commissioners and ambassadors here from the whole of southern Africa and the ones that we have there. Far too often, southern Africa suffers from this fixation of Australia—Australian politicians, policy makers and media—and Australia in general. They are only able to focus on one part of the world at a time. The world is not all that big. It is not too big for us to have interests in various parts of the world.

In conclusion, the two countries that we had most to do with in this inquiry are very ably represented by the two representatives in this country. We are also very ably represented in those countries. We got a tremendous amount of assistance from the South African High Commission here and the Zimbabwe High Commission. Indeed, anything we asked for from our posts in those countries, they supplied us. This was a timely report and I hope that the recommendations that the committee made will be acted on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The nature of any discussion on reports is predicated on when that discussion takes place. As the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has just mentioned, he made a visit to Africa a little while ago. Quite apart from the nature and character of some of the relations between members of that delegation, it is true that time moves on. I think it is sad that some of the recommendations of that report—and indeed, those that we made in our report—have not been implemented. I support the honourable member, particularly as far as representation in Africa is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very concerned about the quality of our overseas representation. While I very strongly support the theory behind the funding cuts in federal government departments, there are a number of areas where I think the product on the ground is less than satisfactory. I do worry that there is talk at the moment, for example, of having one‐person posts, which I think is absolute rubbish. There is no capacity to effectively represent a country—no matter how good the individual—if there is only going to be one person. I think it is tremendously important that we maintain good quality representation abroad. It is important that we maintain an integrity of foreign policy administration. I do not think there is any area where that is more apparent than in South Africa or in southern Africa—indeed, in Africa generally.

The honourable member for Throsby's reference to Ethiopia, of course, extends somewhat outside the boundaries that we are examining in the context of this report that we are debating at the moment. I would also like to commend, as I did in the main chamber, the honourable member for Throsby, through whose initiative in the previous parliament we picked up this report. There were some difficulties in determining boundaries. Unfortunately, the time and the capacity of the committee to examine relations beyond the state of our countries was such that we felt we had to put a line somewhere. We would have liked to have looked at relations with other countries on the African continent. In fact, I think this report is a good one, and the honourable member played a very important part in its initiation and its progress.

There are really three issues that I want to pick up from the report. The first follows a seminar we had on the Commonwealth a few weeks ago. At a time when the traumas following the death of Princess Diana are very much in the news headlines, at a time when our own constitutional convention to consider the future of the monarchical form of government in Australia is moving along towards the conduct of that convention, and with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) having addressed this morning in the main chamber some aspects of his consideration of the republican debate, it is important that we look at the Commonwealth. It is not a British Commonwealth; it is a Commonwealth of nations of which Britain is a member.

It is important that we look at the Commonwealth because the countries in southern Africa that we are talking about are largely members of the Commonwealth. I, for one, have really been pleasantly surprised at the extent to which, within the Commonwealth, there is a real opportunity for us to still work together in another international forum in ways that many of us have tended to cynically regard as being perhaps a little archaic. I can assure everyone that is not so. The product of that seminar—and there will be a report produced, which we will discuss in detail in due course—did emphasise to me that there is an opportunity for Australia, in its role in the Commonwealth, to maintain a dialogue with a relatively smaller group of countries that might otherwise not come together. I say `smaller' while not referring to the size of the countries but to the number of countries participating, and within that group to have very personal discussions. Of course, with the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Edinburgh not far away, there is going to be an opportunity for some of the proposals that we discussed at that seminar to come forward.

I raise this matter in particular in relation to this report because, if people look at the recommendations, they will notice some of our concerns about educational opportunities. I believe quite strongly that part of the great benefits of the Marshall aid plan and the Colombo Plan were the opportunities that they gave the post‐World War II generation to exchange ideas and understanding on a raft of issues. They would never have had a chance to do that if they had not been educated in other countries. My strong view is that, in the educational field, it would have been far better if we had given to a number of overseas students preferred access to this country.

A few years ago, Singapore was just emerging after its split from what was an aborted marriage with Malaysia, and was attempting to establish its role as an industrial country. There is no doubt that in those days a number of young Singaporeans who had been educated in Australia, whether they be engineers, architects, lawyers, accountants or other professionals, looked automatically to Australia as their natural partner. We have got to pick up that theme. In the report that we are examining at the moment, as in that seminar, we have spoken about educational opportunities. Recommendation 34, for example, refers to Australian universities and TAFEs `collectively promoting the opportunities for education, both in‐country and in Australia . . . in southern African countries'. We spoke about a number of other aspects of education throughout the report.

BREAK.PARA: Sadly, it seems to me that through the Commonwealth we have been apparently cutting out some of the preferred access available in the past. I know we have to look at how our universities are funded, but I think that in so many areas it is important to identify what is a foreign policy interest and then establish the best way to promote it. It is not just a matter of the overseas representation to which the member referred; it is the matter of our looking at what is in Australia's long‐term best interests in developing and promoting cooperation and understanding with future generations from other countries—and education is an ideal way by which this can be done.

I believe equally strongly that Radio Australia's Cox Peninsula transmitter, for example, also served a very vital function. I am very disappointed that it has not been reopened and I am hoping that it might be possible for that to be achieved.

What we have to do in Australia is to promote a cooperative and willing relationship with the countries around the world so that we are seen, not as European or American, but as Australian. We can do that by offering educational opportunities through the Commonwealth or, as this says, specifically through Australian institutions with the countries of SADC in a way which ensures that there is an ongoing recognition by those future leaders of those countries that we are their natural partner. In exactly the same way as in the past with Singapore, when they turned to Australia for help and where we had enormous commercial and social advantages out of being an actual partner, we need to do that with the countries of SADC and the Commonwealth. We need to look at ways by which we can extend an understanding in the younger people. If we can do that, there is an enormous advantage for Australia and I think we need to commit some resources to it.

Secondly, with respect to this report, at the moment one of the subcommittees of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is doing an inquiry into our relations with India. As one who comes from an eastern state—as, indeed, do all of us around this room at this time—perhaps we do not see the Indian Ocean in the same way as those who live in Western Australia.

One of the fascinating parts of my childhood was that for those of us interested in collecting stamps there were those that came from a place called Cocos Islands, Indian Ocean. Even the name used to fascinate me. It was something that was way out there; how it came to be part of Australia, I never could quite conceive. But it is, and has been.

It is important that we understand that the Indian Ocean is as significant an area of the world in every way as is the Pacific. It might not have the superpowers: it has not got the United States, for example, and China is not an Indian Ocean power. But it does have India, and India is the second most populous country in the world. We have an Indian minister, Dr Ramaiah, in town at the moment and I think it is great that he is thinking of ways by which those countries of the Indian Ocean rim can work more effectively.

I commend the former foreign minister, the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), for the initiative he took in the meeting in Perth to bring together nations of the region to see whether it could be a focus. It is not an APEC look‐alike—APEC is a different organisation. But I think it is important that we look towards the Indian Ocean.

I give full credit to Dr Mahathir, the Prime Minister of Malaysia.Dr Mahathir and Mr Mandela from South Africa have developed a relationship. They have been visiting each other's countries. They have been taking groups of business people to each other's countries and elsewhere, and they are promoting a link, in part through the Commonwealth and in part bilaterally. We need to understand, as Australians, that if we are not going to be left behind as the economies in the region around us grow, we have to be very active participants in trying to make sure that we develop the same relationship.

The trade with South Africa has grown at surprising rates since we have produced this report, and it is one of the factors that we looked at. Within southern Africa and the SADC countries—and this report refers to them—the relations between South Africa and each of those countries is as a major power with a number of relatively smaller powers. It does not mean that South Africa is setting the pace entirely, but it does mean that it is very important that we develop relations with South Africa commercially and in every political sense so that we can jointly help each others' economic, social and political growth. And as we do so, the long‐term benefit is the security and the stability that flows, and we are looking at that in terms of where we go.

Indeed, in the report we also refer to ongoing medical and rehabilitation assistance to landmine victims. We talk about community education on landmines and training for local people in demining methods, because we can see the product of the instability that has been so apparent in so many of those countries for so long—during the days of apartheid, and even now.

The final thing I want to say relates to the next matter before us. Freedom from corruption, a free press, an independent administration, an impartial police force, and what we in the West call good governance are still fundamental in each of the countries of the region. I know the traumas that President Mandela has had in his government, trying to bring together those who were part of the apartheid regime and incorporating everybody, in particular the significant black majority, into the modern government of South Africa.

But in other countries of the region there has not been the political stability that one would hope for. I do not know how we allow these countries to grow and develop and how we give them the opportunities for what we call good governance to prevail. In many there is corruption in government, one party government, a press that is dictated to rather than allowed free expression, a police force which is inadequately paid and unable to operate as it might, and public servants who are inadequately paid and unable to act in an impartial way. Above all, many lack an independent judicial system where the rule of law allows individual human rights to be respected. These are all parts of the process.

I am one of those who totally oppose the idea that Dr Mahathir has been promoting that there be some form of alternative Atlantic Charter, suggesting that some collective human rights are far more significant than individual human rights. Unless we respect the rights of each individual to their share of space under the sun, I do not believe the countries of the world are going to be able to live in peace with each other. If a country has collective rights, that inevitably leads to repression and to the abuse of power by individuals; and that, of course, is totally unacceptable.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I do commend this report to the government, and trust that it might serve in some way to advance relations between the countries of southern Africa and Australia. They are very important to us, geographically and in the world, and perhaps it might be another way by which we can look at our future relations within the Commonwealth; for there, too, there is a great deal that can be done to promote Australia's future influence in the wider world.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ted Grace) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Mr Taylor:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am sorry to inflict myself on the Main Committee again immediately, but I want to say a few things about the report from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade seminar on Papua New Guinea. I am glad that the report has been referred to the committee. When Sir John Coles, the permanent under‐secretary to the foreign affairs department of the United Kingdom, asked me what I thought was Australia's major foreign policy priority, I told him it was our relations with PNG.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many bilateral and multilateral fora in which Australia participates. One looks at the population in Indonesia and other nations in ASEAN, one looks at the economies of those countries and one looks at our relations with Asia generally. It might be said that given PNG's four million people odd, and given its proximity to Australia, it would hardly be seen as our major foreign policy priority.

To my mind, Papua New Guinea is our priority, and it will be forever, for one simple reason. We need to understand in Australia that PNG is not part of Australia. It is a separate nation, and an independent nation. It is dependent on us, but it is independent from us.

We need to make sure that in our dealings with the people of PNG we give them help and encouragement so they can remain internally stable; so they can free themselves from the corruption and greed which tragically seems to be almost endemic in some of their political processes; and so they can operate freely in a way which allows that extraordinarily diverse country, with more than 600 languages and with 800 different ethnic and tribal groups, to bind together to become a modern nation.

We do have an enormous responsibility in this country to provide a sympathetic ear and help and guidance, but to allow them always to be an independent nation and to see themselves in a way which ensures that we do not set the policies for them. We can help them so that, in setting their own policies, they can play a worthwhile and stable part in this region of the world where so many changes have occurred in recent years.

This report was an update of an earlier inquiry we did on Papua New Guinea. Its recommendations were intended to try to ensure that we looked at some of the ongoing problems. I am not going to deal with them all. Perhaps, again, there are three that I should talk about. Bougainville is predominant. The second is the extent to which, in relations between the new industries, particularly the mining industry, and traditional land‐holders, there can be a meaningful negotiation which allows each to benefit. That, of course, is not dissimilar to the problem between the people on Bougainville and those operating the Panguna mine. Until you have got a meaningful relationship which allows you to use the resources, the people of the region are not going to be able to get the full benefit. But you have got to do it in a way which is open, apparent and brings equal benefit to everybody.

With the first issue I mentioned, in Bougainville you are not going to be able to look at how you are going to reopen the mine until you have settled the problems of Bougainville, and I will come back to that in a moment.

The third problem, which is really the significant part of where we are now, is to go on from this report and see things as they are on 3 September 1997 with a new Prime Minister and a new government. I will just talk a little bit from there and then come back to the other two issues.

The first thing I should say is that the joint committee was very fortunate to have an excellent briefing from Professor Ron May and Anthony Regan of the Australian National University earlier this week. I felt they gave us an outstanding analysis of where we are in the Bougainville negotiations and also of the consequence of the election of Prime Minister Bill Skate, and gave us some perception of where they think the government is going. They are two committed Australians, and I think we are very fortunate we have men like them, and others, who academically and personally remain committed to PNG. It is of great concern—and is one of the reasons that we produced the report—that so many younger Australians do not really give the emphasis and perhaps understanding to PNG that there was amongst those who were patrol officers or members of the then colonial administration in PNG. It is not a matter of suggesting we go back to some form of colonial relationship, but I would certainly very much like to see large numbers of younger Australians being involved in PNG.

The paradox, as those of us who have been there know, is that everything that happens in Australia is seen and known and felt to be part of the lives of villagers in PNG. They listen to our radio. They listen to our television. They are more committed to Rugby League and what happens there and the traumas of the dispute with Super League than I think half of the Australians you might talk to are, simply because it is very much real to them that we are like big brother. Because we had a colonial relationship, it does give us a fairly unique connection.

We have got to understand that they recognise us, they know a little bit about us and they aspire in some ways to be like us, but they want to be their own version. Yet there are so few of the younger generation of Australians who know a great deal about PNG. I think one of the challenges we have, and we talked about it in this report, is to get the next generation of Australians—today's generation of business managers and professionals—interested in PNG and to recognise the way in which our mutual connection is going to be important for each of us into the future.

The new government is one about which I mentioned that Professor May and Anthony Regan had advised us. Theirs are subjective judgments. I think we all look at the election of Bill Skate and hope that it will be able to provide honest, fair and competent administration. There are enormous challenges for the country. The infrastructures are really very poor. The communications base leaves a lot to be desired. You still cannot travel, for example, from Port Moresby to the highlands. You cannot travel from Port Moresby to Lae by road. Those who have seen the Kokoda Trail agree it is a remarkable mountain range and it is a very physical barrier. It is going to be a major challenge to try and provide even the concept of PNG as people living in the one country.

In Australia, we have enough troubles trying to get—dare I say it—Queenslanders to think as Australians at times, or Western Australians or Tasmanians to think as Australians. We tend to think of our own region and of its priorities. So in a place where many have not travelled that far out of their own village, and to do so they have to walk miles over fairly steep and precipitous paths, it is no wonder it is like that. Until we overcome that problem, the challenges for any government are enormous.

We all wish Bill Skate well. It is an enormous challenge. Sadly, there were a number of fundamental mistakes made, quite apart from the Sandline affair, by the government of the then Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan. I have known Julius through all his political career and I feel sad that he was not able to bring together the parties within Bougainville in the way he originally committed himself in the early days of his administration.

Bill Skate seems to be starting off in negotiating quite admirably in Bougainville—and I want to talk about that shortly. We certainly wish him well. He needs to make sure that the press remains open and fair. He needs to be quite conscious that if there is corruption in his administration, people are going to be very sceptical of the outcome. I do not like the vote buying process that operates in PNG; I am very apprehensive about the way in which there seem to be favours gained for contributions made. I do not think that is a practice which any of us in Australia see as one which will enable a fair and dispassionate administration. One would hope that as a cleanskin, if you like, Prime Minister Bill Skate will be able to set new standards and therefore maintain an administration in an open and just way.

Fortunately, there is a judiciary there which is impartial and all of us who have seen something of it have a great admiration for the way in which it operates. Of course, the second inquiry into the Sandline affair is being conducted in an impartial and dispassionate way. That is not just in the judiciary; there is also a free press, which I think is wonderful. But there is a need for something more; there needs to be a move away from the wantok system. Those of us who know the place know of the enormous problems in trying to treat everybody equitably; and, regrettably, in PNG the wantok system seems to deny that. It is a big challenge for Prime Minister Skate and his administration to ensure they govern for all PNG people and not just for the few.

On Bougainville, Anthony Regan gave us an excellent briefing. Our foreign minister, Alexander Downer, committed himself and the government to a process which is now fortunately accepted by the Skate administration, as it was in its dying days by the Chan administration. This process, from what they call the Barter report, is a process of getting people out of the care centres in Bougainville, of re‐establishing negotiations between the parties and establishing a peaceful cease‐fire from which there can be a restoration of normal village life and commercial activity in Bougainville.

The foreign minister has undertaken to provide $100 million of Australian aid to Bougainville over the course of the next five years. That is very good, but we have been offering aid for years and it has not been capable of being delivered because of the security conditions there. That is a problem. When Stephen Loosley, who was then Senator Loosley, and Senator Vicki Bourne and I visited there some years ago, we certainly looked very closely at what we might be able to do to try and open a few of the ports there. Senator Calvert was also a member of that delegation. The difficulty we found was that the security risk prevented the aid being given. If you could only open Buin, for example, in the south, you would be able to get the local village crops sold and get a cash flow into the economy, and people would be able to start living in a normal way. That, to my mind, is fundamental.

I commend Mr Regan; I thought his address to us the other day was excellent. There is hope through the New Zealand initiative—and full marks to the New Zealanders for taking that initiative. They have been able to bring the parties together. I am not going to talk about individuals, but I do hope that Francis Ona participates in the process and I hope that he is prepared to accept the judgment that has been made by others, that it is not now a question of looking at any one issue in the peace talks.

In order to have peace talks, the parties have to agree to a cease‐fire. They have to get the people out of the care centres and back into the villages to allow the village economy to resume. From there, they will have some prospect of being able to re‐establish normal communications from which they have a chance to talk about the fundamental issues. If you have a dispute with anyone, it is no use talking about the things where you totally disagree; it is better to start with the things where you can agree.

People need to remember that Bougainville is a matrilineal society. I have always advocated that women, to a far greater degree, should be allowed to participate in the negotiations there. On the visits that I have made to Bougainville, I have been very impressed with the quality of the women there. Sister Veronica Brady was one of those who attended the peace talks that were held there some little while ago. I think it is a great tragedy that the women have not been allowed to play a greater role. I remember when Sister Veronica came back she spoke of the tremendous goodwill that there was amongst all of the women, many of whom were from different faiths—some were Protestants, some were Catholic. There were people there with different prejudices and different wantok.

Of course, a matrilineal society only means that there is an inheritance through the female line. It does not mean that the women have the authority. The men have to accept that, if they are going to re‐establish normal life in the villages and get Bougainville together again, they have to give status to women in those negotiations, and not just allow a nominal presence of a women in the negotiations. If that happened, I think everybody would be better off. That is the only real advice that I would have in that area. I hope that the next round of talks, to which Australia is prepared to give whatever assistance it can, are successful.

The final thing is that there is a necessity for all mining ventures, for all investment projects, to take account of the interests of the villagers. There are obviously always problems in trying to determine how sustainable commercial operations can be undertaken. I think it is particularly important that there is a recognition by the villagers that there is long-term benefit for them, for employment, in allowing companies to take advantage of the rich resources that are there.

I hope that under Prime Minister Bill Skate there is the chance to give PNG the future that we all want it to have—that is, a stable one with opportunities for better education, health, welfare, and a stable family environment within the village structure. There are enormous challenges ahead and we wish Prime Minister Skate well in his task. We trust that, in the dialogue that has to be ongoing between Australia and PNG, particularly through project aid and the way in which our very generous aid program is now maintained, some hope can come out of the trauma of the Sandline affair which, last year, seemed to have ended in absolute disaster. We trust that under a new Prime Minister there is a future and we wish them well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always very difficult to follow the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) in some of these debates. I do not want to be repetitive but I want to mention some of the things that he has raised. I agree with the right honourable gentleman that this is an important report about an important country as part of our bilateral relationships. I will come back to that in a moment in terms of the wider foreign affairs and trade policy white paper which was tabled very recently by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer).

SPEECH.PARA: l was very pleased to chair this seminar over two days in November. Most of the issues are still there and have not really been addressed substantively. Like the right honourable gentleman who spoke before me, I commend to the government the 14 recommendations in the report.

BREAK.PARA: I think there are a number of people that this parliament has to thank for the success of what was a groundbreaking seminar. We have had a number of seminars since then but, as I said, I will come back to those.

I think we need first to thank His Excellency Ken Noga, the PNG high commissioner here in Canberra, without whose cooperation and contribution this seminar would not have been possible. We owe a vote of thanks to Vice Admiral David Leach—the Chief of Naval Staff when I was serving—as the president of the Australia‐PNG friendship group. David Leach played an important part over those two days in ensuring the success of the seminar.

I thank my parliamentary colleagues and, indeed, everybody who contributed, whether they be academics, whether they be business people, both in Australia and in PNG. We did have a large contribution from those in Papua New Guinea conversant with what goes on in terms of life up there at the moment.

I want particularly to congratulate the right honourable member for New England—but not to embarrass him—because this really is a groundbreaking report. It concerns the first of a series of seminars held in this parliament within this Joint Standing Committee of Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I know such an approach has been tried with varying degrees of success in the past, but this was the first seminar series. Subsequently we have had a very successful one‐day aid seminar, which was attended by a wide range of people. We have had a two‐day seminar on the very important ANZUS alliance.
