A lot of the credit for the establishment of that concept goes to the right honourable gentleman, and I take the opportunity to congratulate him. I hope that for the remainder of this parliament we will continue with that concept of seminars, because I think it is important that we maintain a dialogue and that that dialogue is, very importantly, two‐way. With respect to this seminar and subsequent ones, particularly the ANZUS seminar, I understand—unfortunately, I was not able to attend either the ANZUS or the Commonwealth seminar—there was a lot of positive feedback. I think that says a lot for the processes that have been put in train.
This report makes 14 recommendations, all of importance but in varying ways. I want to highlight the last one:

14 the Australian Government recognise the significance of Papua New Guinea in its foreign policy priorities and acknowledge through the maintenance of the AusAid and Defence Cooperation Programs the unique challenges that Papua New Guinea faces in building its administrative capacity, in developing its infrastructure—
which Mr Sinclair has referred to—
particularly in health, education and employment generation, in improving law and order and in resolving—
that festering sore—
the Bougainville crisis peacefully.

I think that, in the most recent tabling of a white paper, a lot of those issues have been addressed and accepted strategically by the present government in terms of where we are heading with that most critical bilateral relationship. The white paper, at paragraph 23, says:

While the spread of Australia's interests is wide, each of these interests is not equally important and nor can they be pursued with equal resource. Care is needed in setting priorities. The Asia‐Pacific is the region of highest foreign and trade policy priority for the government. Within the Asia‐Pacific, Australia's most substantial interests are with the region's three major powers and largest economies, the United States, Japan and China, and with our largest neighbour, Indonesia. Significant Australian interests are also engaged in our relationship with the Republic of Korea, the other ASEAN states and in the South Pacific, New Zealand and Papua New Guinea.

The point I want to make as a result of that generalised statement is that I hope that, although Papua New Guinea comes last, that does not indicate our national priorities. I agree with the right honourable gentleman that one of our highest priorities, if not our highest, is that bilateral relationship with Papua New Guinea. To be fair, later in the same white paper, there is a very extensive coverage, in four paragraphs, of that bilateral relationship.

The bottom line is the statement that a united, stable and prosperous PNG is of major Australian interest. That is the point to emphasise in terms of this debate and this report. Like the right honourable gentleman, I also agree that there are a lot of challenges for Papua New Guinea. There are challenges, particularly for the new Prime Minister, Bill Skate, whether they be in terms of the maintenance—or, some might say, the restoration—of parliamentary democracy or at least representative democracy or something else. There is no doubt that it is a very volatile society, and the Prime Minister will have his hands full in terms of the maintenance and, in fact, the sustenance of that parliamentary democracy with true representation.

Those challenges are ahead of him. Of course, a large element of that is the maintenance of internal security, particularly on the island of Bougainville. From our very valuable briefings only a few days ago from Professor Ron May and Tony Regan from ANU, we got a different perspective. We get departmental and ministerial perspectives, but it is very healthy at times to get the perspective of people who are right on the ground. Both of those gentlemen, from different points of view, are across the issues of Papua New Guinea—in Ron May's case, particularly the election and the electoral consequences of what happened a few months ago; and in Tony Regan's case, particularly the Bougainville festering sore. I hope that the new Prime Minister takes up—and I am sure he will—the baton and charges all of those issues well.

In terms of Bougainville, I want to take the opportunity to pay tribute to the New Zealanders and to Minister MacKinnon—and, indeed, to our own foreign minister—in relation to their efforts in resolving what is a very difficult situation. But, as Mr Sinclair indicated, the aid package, $100 million over the next four years, will be only as good as Papua New Guinea makes it. And so it comes right back to Prime Minister Skate and his government, and the ability that they have to come to grips with all of the issues in their society—and, in particular, those that continue to fester out on Bougainville.

I do not want to hold up this place any longer than I have to, because I know there are other speakers, other than to say that I hope that our government will take up and consider these recommendations. They are very well substantiated as a result of the seminar. In particular, I hope that both PNG and Bougainville, in relation to recommendation 14, which is the overarching recommendation for that bilateral relationship, will accept the consequences and the results of what was a most important seminar and what is, indeed, a most important report to the parliament of this country.
Debate (on motion by Mr Slipper) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 August, on motion by Mr Reid:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity today to speak in the debate on the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, their report being Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia . In doing so, it is appropriate to refer to the work of the equivalent committee in the last parliament with the production of the Beddall report. That provided excellent groundwork, and I understand that many of the outcomes of that report were well under way prior to the 1996 election. I would like to particularly take the opportunity to quote a couple of parts from the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On reading this report, and on discussing it with representatives of my community, the importance of the report has become increasingly apparent in relation to small business in the community being able to continue in a fair and proper fashion. I would like to quote from the foreword of the report. One part says:

Because it plays such a vital role, small business is a top priority for the Government. In particular the Government has committed itself to listen to the concerns of small business, to address those concerns and to subject its policies to a process of continuous improvement.
It goes on to say:

After a detailed investigation, the Committee has concluded that concerns about unfair business conduct towards small business are justified, and should be addressed urgently. In an endeavour to find a balance towards fair trading in Australia, the Committee has recommended a number of specific measures, including legislation, to induce behavioural change on the part of big business towards smaller business, and to provide unfairly treated small businesses with adequate means of redress. These proposals will provide small business with a fair deal.
These two quotes out of the foreword of the report, I believe, set the scene for what we hope will be a government response appropriate to those words.

There has been much comment made from all sides of business and politics about the importance of small business in our economy and in the fight against unemployment. There is absolutely no doubt about that importance. The reality is quite clear. Much of our hope for employment opportunity is stored in our small business sector. That sector, however, cannot deliver if we do not give them the ground upon which to operate.

The fair trading inquiry recommendations provide an answer to the prayers of thousands of small businesses and their employees. The tough legislative action that it recommends is supported by the Labor Party. It has been common knowledge that small businesses—particularly in the retail, tenancy and franchise environment—have been badly treated by big business for a long time. However, the sheer extent of the problem has been starkly illustrated by this inquiry. I appreciate the concern and frustration felt by thousands of small businesses in Australia. It should be clear to anyone who reads this report that small business is struggling under the weight of market power abuse by big business. Many local small businesses in my electorate have spoken to me at length about that frustration.

Since taking the opportunity of circulating the recommendations to a very broad number of people operating smaller businesses and franchises within my electorate, I know that I have a regular attendance in my office each week during my constituency meetings of people from small business. They want to come to explain and talk about the difficulties which they face and which they know can be addressed by the adoption of this report.

My electorate of Namadgi—and Canberra as a whole—has many small businesses suffering severely under the current economic circumstances. The Canberra economy is struggling and we are desperately looking for signs of sustained recovery. It will happen and we know that. But what we do not know is when that recovery will occur. Canberra has faced and survived hard economic times in the past and we will recover eventually, due in no small part to the determination of our business people, and, particularly, our small businesses. But they need a fair go, a fair chance. This report offers them that fair go.

Small business in the main is a family investment. These families put all their resources and energies into their business, with nothing other than an intention to succeed. Is it fair that oppressive or unconscionable behaviour by larger businesses is allowed to continue? No, it is not. It drives these people out of those businesses.

The range of recommendations covered in this report are important to note. I will just very briefly outline them. They refer to the Trade Practices Act, retail tenancy, franchising, small business finance and access to justice and education in the main. The inquiry recommended many useful changes. However, the most important element is the legislative protection for small business through the Trade Practices Act. Without this, the implementation of the recommendations would be useless. I should point out here that prior to the inquiry the Labor Party had proposed such legislation.

My Labor parliamentarian colleagues and I fully support all of the recommendations, including legislative recommendations, because they are fair. We feel very strongly that, if small business can get some security and certainty, then employment growth will follow.
The recommendations in the report are essential for small business and must be implemented by the federal government. The committee chair, the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), said in the report:

Unfair conduct by big business towards small business is one such major concern. Indeed it has been a matter of grave concern for many years. Not only has such conduct the potential to impact heavily on the economic health of the small business sector, and on the allocation of resources generally, it can also involve heavy social costs.

We believe that what small business really wants above all else is a law that protects them from the misuse of market power by big business. Mr Rob Bastian, Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, described the need for it more than a year ago as `critical' and surpassing such matters as `deregulation and reduced paperwork'.

In Canberra, with the cutbacks to the Public Service and the subsequent flow‐on into our private sector, our businesses are really struggling. But they are not going to give up. Both the federal and the ACT Liberal governments have stated many times their expectation that the private sector will pick up the slack from the changes to the public sector. I have heard so many times that accordingly jobs will come from the private sector. Well, people in the private sector are trying, and I can assure you that that is not because the two Liberal governments concerned have suggested that they should, but because they happen to believe in Canberra, in the role of the national capital, and in the future of this city. But give them the real opportunity.

Discussion following the issuing of this report has been mainly in the retail area, and that is very understandable, given the very structure of that particular area of business. Another area that has a whole chapter—3.57, in fact—devoted to it in the report is that of petrol franchising and the outlets.

I have had the opportunity in my work in the ACT over previous years—in another place—to participate in an inquiry into petrol pricing. What became incredibly obvious to me during that inquiry in another parliament was the absolute power that the oil companies had, and still have, over families operating franchises in petrol outlets. It has been absolutely outrageous. In fact, at one point, I was known to say, `Why would any family ever wish to enter such a business, given the overwhelming power by which they are held by the oil companies?'

It is good to see that quite a proportion of this report has referred to that particular area of business. I know that it is no secret to all members in this place, should they read the correspondence they get, that the Motor Trades Association has taken a very strong stand of support in relation to this report and wants to see it implemented on behalf of its membership as soon as possible. Regarding that sector, paragraph 3.78 from the report says:

The Committee notes again that a high level of concern has been expressed about the conduct of the major oil companies in their relationships with their franchisees and that those concerns have had a very long history. The Committee also notes that similar concerns have led to specific regulatory action in the United States.

It is urgent for everybody—every group, family and individual—who operates within a small business sector in Australia to have this report adopted, unequivocally, as soon as possible and for the legislative requirements accompanying that to be enacted as soon as possible.

Adopt this report and implement the recommendations with no delay. Small businesses understand very well that, with the implementation of these recommendations, their opportunities for growth and for increased employment—their future, in fact—will improve immediately. So too will the economic future of this city and this region where I happen to be a parliamentary representative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It was our former great Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, who once so eloquently said that life was not meant to be easy. Political observers at the time put the reference down to the politics of the day. In the 1990s, it could well be applied to an individual, couple, family or partnership running their own small business. When we look back on the past, and to the wisdom of other men like the great late Sir Garfield Barwick who so recently passed away, we also think of a Liberal politician who first proposed the Trade Practices Act, which today is a critical piece of legislation in the protection of small business.

SPEECH.PARA: As a new boy on the block in this parliament, and as a fresh face in the new federal coalition government, it is with a great deal of satisfaction that I present a report to this House on the inquiry into fair trading by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology.

The Howard government honoured an important commitment it made to the small business community and to the people of Australia, before its election to office in March last year, by announcing on 26 June 1996 an inquiry into fair trading. In the federal coalition's policy document, A new deal for small business, we committed ourselves to ensuring that the Trade Practices Act could respond to the working needs of the small business sector. It stated:
Monitoring of fair trading practices will be a priority issue.

It is from this background and as a member of the committee that I support the overwhelmingly bipartisan recommendations brought down in the report, Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia , on 26 May this year.

I offer no dissent to the final recommendations, and there is a simple reason for that. I support the broad thrust of those recommendations and what they seek to achieve. Unfair conduct by big business towards small business is a legitimate concern and needs to be addressed by this government, as it promised it would.

Assessing the need to restore the balance in retail tenancy and lease arrangements by way of a uniform retail tenancy code, underpinned by the Trade Practices Act, will help level the playing field that so many small business people have long felt needed to be done, and as they have proved during the hearings of this inquiry.

The three‐part recommendation dealing with franchising, the fastest growing sector in Australian small business today, is well warranted. The upside potential of owning a franchise has tantalised small businesses for much of the 1980s and 1990s, and with good reason. As Professor Andrew Terry said about franchising in evidence to the committee, and as it is quoted in the report on page 83:
It is undoubtedly the most efficient, effective distribution system ever invented. It is the greatest invention of Western capitalism since the invention of the corporation.

Yes, it has been, but that promise has been weakened by the pitfalls small business has succumbed to due to the limited protection provided under the present Franchising Code of Practice. The code is no saving grace for many hundreds of small business franchisees around the nation. It is time the rules and regulations pertaining to franchising matched the reality of the marketplace. I am encouraged by the inquiry's recommendations that seek to restore equity and balance, and the ethos of a fair go, in the area of franchising.

I have supreme faith in the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), who has done an unprecedented job in dragging our industrial relations system from the 19th century into the 21st century. The five significant recommendations of the fair trading report concerning fairness, equity, balance, and most of all, a fair go for small business, will be introduced effectively and in a sensible way.

Our community in general, and many small businesses in particular, greet our federal small business minister with the sounds of positive endorsement since the interests of small business are his interests. The confidence is there, and I have confidence that a better deal on fair trading for small business is around the corner.

Peter Reith made a very successful trip to the Hunter and Paterson electorates on 30 July this year. At a business luncheon that was fitted in at Newcastle—Labor's heartland, its beating pulse, as they like to think it is—the minister saw first‐hand that the people expected something to be done, and that they expected it would be done.

The fair trading report will go down in history as a report of great significance. It will not be a dust collector on a library shelf, as happens to so many good parliamentary reports despite their good intent and all the hours of work and all the resources that have gone into them. It will not be a report where people will say, `Tut tut, nice ideas, but let's put it aside for another time.'

There are several reasons for that. Firstly, the inquiry sought far and wide the views of small businesses and interested industry groups and individuals and hence the interest in its findings. There is nothing unusual in that, but the submissions and expressions of support to the inquiry in most cases were second to none.

Small business people in the Hunter were particularly well represented in the 198 submissions and a multitude of exhibits. I publicly offer my support of those people in the Hunter region, and in particular those who have prepared a case to see the Commonwealth foster a fairer and more equitable arrangement for enterprise and small business in this country and in its future.

The inquiry report thanked the contribution made by a number of local people. These include Grahame Henderson, the national chairman of the Shell National Action Group and a local service station proprietor. He made two submissions and provided an exhibit for the inquiry. He has constantly contacted me over his concern about multi‐site franchising and the unconscionable conduct of Shell towards its franchisees and the reneging on its previous offers.

Other Hunter people to provide submissions in that inquiry viewed as not in‐confidence included Graham Poole, Chairman of the Retail Committee Small Business Association for the Hunter region; Vicki Holliday, the director of the Port Stephens Sand Company Proprietary Ltd; Great Cuts Hairdressing of Charlestown Square; Mr David Roskell; and Mr Bill Roberts, Vice‐President of the Hunter Small Business Persons Association, who gave evidence under the umbrella of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia. Of others, it was notable that Tim Luckhurst, Executive Director of the Australian Chicken Growers Council, also made a submission to the inquiry.

There has been plenty written and said lately about the chicken industry in the Hunter, and a lot of hairy chest stuff from my political opponent, as if Labor had all the answers to the issue. I make the salient point on this: the former government was a part of the problem with the chicken industry and the ongoing debate over the importation of cooked chicken meat, so how can they be a part of the solution?

My strident stand against the importation of cooked chicken meat from the nations of Thailand, the United States and Denmark, which possess exotic diseases such as the virulent Newcastle disease, is well‐known. I publicly again reiterate my wholehearted opposition to it.

My second point reiterates an important point I highlighted earlier. The government has categorically stated that it will take the findings on board, and will respond in no set timetable but now likely to be some time this month. Indeed, only yesterday the minister addressed both the urgency and the importance of the fair trading report to the coalition members of this parliament. The response to the report will not be locked away in the bottom drawer, so let us not have any of this talk about that.

Thirdly, the report is also unusual in that for the first time a federal government—that being the Howard government—elected in part on the back of small business support, is showing a leadership role in the important areas of retail tenancy and unfair and unconscionable business conduct. That is an important step that reflects the Commonwealth's ability to readdress policy to suit the times with small business.

This is not a government that speaks from upon high and then expects people to be boxed around the ears by the message. It is a government prepared to offer some spine of solid lasting support for small business where it can. It is a government that is prepared and is delivering a fairer go for small business.

BREAK.PARA: Back on 5 August, the Hunter based small business people in Newcastle held a public debate over the fair trading report, with the respective members of the inquiry addressing Hunter businesses on their desire for a fair go over fair trading. I was there with my colleague, the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the member for Newcastle (Mr Morris), the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin)—Labor's opposition small business spokesman—and the Democrats' business spokesperson, Senator Andrew Murray. You might call that a star‐studded cast, but there was plenty of pulpit thumping there. All took up the fight for a better deal for small business. I hope that show of support carries through to other policy areas that assist in enterprise and foster growth and job creation.

Sadly, as I pointed out to this House last week, a fair go for small business for Labor and the Democrats does not extend to relief from unfair dismissal provisions; a fair go for small business did not include a balanced budget that has driven rates down.

A fair go for small business includes exemption from fringe benefits tax from 1 April 1997 for car parking; capital gains tax rollover relief on the sale of small business for retirement and the sale of shares in small business, and a new apprenticeship system more attractive for small businesses to take on new apprentices and trainees. With my own eyes on the stage, I watched them state how they would fight for small business and drag the government towards fully endorsing bipartisan findings on the fair trading inquiry—an inquiry I add that this government actually created and instigated.

So Senator Murray and the member for Cunningham, rightly, want the fish and chip outlet, the clothes shop in a shopping centre and the fruito next door to a supermarket to get a fair go on fair trading, but, it seems, nowhere else. Those fighting words do not carry through to providing some valid relief from unfair dismissal provisions for these very same businesses, and supporting them in actually employing people. That is the point I want to ram home hard.

The Australian business climate, whilst it offers many opportunities, offers some harsh realities. As a nation, Australia is the world leader in square metres of retail space per head of population. That is a pretty scaring statistic. In Australia as a nation, it is generally accepted and not disputed that of every 10 new businesses that open their doors, only one will still be trading after five years—because of retirement, new opportunities, not earning enough dollars, whatever the reason.

As a nation, for much of the past two or so decades we have had governments—federal, state and local—which have lived beyond their means, and business has paid the penalty through higher taxes, charges and interest rates. I understand very much where small business is coming from. For all the breast beating I hear from my political opponents, this government is proud to build a working partnership with the small business community. As a former small businessman myself, in the water sports business, I experienced the hard knocks as well as the pleasures, the individual freedoms, the ability to carve out your life for a period as a small business person. Sure, it is never easy. Successes do not follow you with every turn, and there are plenty of pitfalls on the way.

As a current political representative, in July 1996—as promised during the campaign—I held a very successful small business summit, hosting the then small business minister, the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), and including speakers of the calibre of John Farragher, representing the Hunter small business persons, and Dr Wej Paradice from the Hunter Valley Research Foundation. I have taken on board the great feedback and ideas I got from it, and continue to get, particularly with the recent Hunter visit by the new small business minister, a man of great reputation for getting things done—the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith).

The bottom line is this. We would always like the economy to be a bit better; our customers to be more friendly, with conditions more conducive to their spending; our creditors to pay us on time; the impost of council rates and other charges to be less. What we need now is new corridors of opportunity to be opened. What we need in this country is quite simply a fair go for small businesses to get on with what they do best: creating wealth and employing people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —For political scientists in the future, particularly following the speech we have just heard, there will be some really fascinating things to study about the Howard government. One is the way that it seems to take things for granted. Another is the way that it seems to feel that if you say something often enough it will become a fact.

SPEECH.PARA: At the last election, older Australians were solid supporters of the coalition. But since he became Prime Minister, John Howard has not missed an opportunity to betray that trust. He has cut older Australians' access to dental care, restricted hearing services and restricted the full range of drugs they need, and is making them sell their homes if they need to get into a nursing home. That is as far as it goes for older people and the coalition.

Today we are talking about small business. On jobs and the economy the government keeps saying, `Things will get better,' and `Just wait a few months.' Meanwhile, its only proactive moves are to continue to cut government services and assistance across the board. Probably most blatant and most astounding of all is the way this government has treated small business—in particular, small retailers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very well.

—Those opposite say that it is very well. When I give them a few details, in a few minutes, they may change their tune. Small business is acknowledged by the opposition as well as by the government to be the engine room of the economy and a critical factor in job creation. We know that the preferred option of the Prime Minister when it comes to job creation is to go down the American road and cut wages. Let me tell the Prime Minister and those opposite that, for many small retailers in the electorate of Jagajaga, this is just not an option. Let us look at why.

SPEECH.PARA: Thanks to the way this government has handled the economy, generally, and the way it has handled the environment in which small retailers have to work, specifically, many small retailers are doing it so hard that they cannot afford to employ any staff at all. Most are now in a situation where it is husband, wife and kids working around the clock just to keep things going.

The Prime Minister might skite about the record number of interest rate cuts which have had to occur because of the appalling state the economy is in, but the local retailers are telling us that interest rate cuts are having a zero effect on their businesses. People who live in Jagajaga shop at either of the two large shopping centres: Northland, which is actually in the neighbouring electorate of Batman, or Greensborough, which is on the border of Jagajaga and Scullin. Otherwise they shop in a variety of retail strip shopping centres scattered throughout the electorate. All of the retailers are having difficulties, thanks to the policies of this government, which are exacerbated by the policies of their coalition colleague, but not friend, Jeff Kennett.

BREAK.PARA: But I will here focus on the problems of the retailers in the larger centres rather than the strip shopping centres.

All Australian retailers, including those locally, are struggling to cope with the difficulties caused by a flat economy and a lack of consumer confidence. That is what this government has created. Victorian retailers have the additional problems caused by the Kennett government's push to a seven days a week, 24 hours a day trading regime, coupled with the wholesale expansion of gambling. The former—the 24 hours, seven days a week trading—stretches the resources of small retailers just to keep trading, while gambling has been well documented in its adverse impact on retail spending.

But at least many strip retailers have a choice about their hours of operation. For the retailers in the large centres, even that choice is taken away from them. They also face constantly increasing rents and government charges. Those opposite might go out into some of their large retail shopping centres and hear about the 300 to 500 per cent increases in rents that are occurring in the large shopping centres, certainly in my electorate. Lacking the clout of the big chains, many of the small retailers in these shopping centres are unable to get good deals on other things as well.

What is hardest for them to bear is the callous and indifferent attitude of the centre managements. At Northland we have had renovations that started in February and will continue until the end of the year with devastating impacts for the passing trade. Centre managements seem to be indifferent to the problems: they just want the rent. In fact, they want the rent and they want no rocking of the boat. When Steve Price from local radio station 3AW, a Victorian radio station, visited Northland recently to talk to small retailers, he was followed everywhere by five centre security guards who noticed every retailer he visited. The message of intimidation was clear. In both centres, in Northland and in Greensborough, large numbers of retailers are simply closing the doors and walking away from their businesses. But this is after they have broken their bank balances and often their health and spirit in trying to keep their businesses running.

Increasingly one hears of small retailers mortgaging their homes, taking extra loans just to keep going and then losing the lot. These people are being crushed by big business landlords, the mates of this government, who until recently really rubbed salt into the wounds of small retailers by having as a small business minister a person who himself was a shopping centre landlord. That was a message clearly understood by small retailers. The Howard government is a government for big business, for the top end of town, and has no interest in small business except to try to get their votes at election time. Where is this government's vision for small business? Nothing sums it up better than a comparison of the election promise to reduce red tape for small business and the recent proposals to introduce a GST. A GST involves a massive amount of extra red tape and paperwork and turns all small businesses into tax collectors for this government.
The fair trading inquiry recommendations are a big step in the right direction for helping small retailers. The tough legislative action recommended by the inquiry is supported by Labor.

We are committed to implementing the recommendations of the fair trading inquiry and believe that this, coupled with our small business policy principles, will go some way to helping the very difficult situation that many small retailers find themselves in. The report takes economic growth seriously through government assistance rather than blind adherence to market economics, which, of course, we see from the Treasurer (Mr Costello). It supports protection for small business against unfair trading through government monitoring of franchise arrangements. It supports protection of the small business against the large one, and making big business pay a fair share of taxation. It supports greater supervision of banks and the finance sector generally to help small businesses, who are often at a disadvantage. There is a greater recognition of the needs of the regions and specific programs to assist them, and there is support for the creation of a workplace atmosphere of reciprocal obligation between small retailers and their employees. These can be summarised as fair service and fair treatment.

As a stage in the process of helping small retailers with their problems and shaping Labor's policies for the future, I am going to be sponsoring a forum for small retailers in Heidelberg in the north‐east of Melbourne next week. Stephen Martin, our shadow minister for small business, and Lisa Michaels, the president of United Retailers—who I must say have been tireless in their efforts for small business—will be attending the forum. I look forward to hearing the views of small business and small retailers in the electorate so that we can bring to this parliament some serious ways of improving the plight that these people find themselves in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must acknowledge the comments of the previous speaker, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), and acknowledge that many of the things she said are true. However, I point out that two issues are fairly critical. Firstly, small business has been doing it tough for a long time—probably for at least 13 years or more under the previous Labor government. You have to ask yourself what they actually did for small business, and my answer is: not a lot. It took courage to go out and find where the problems are in the small business community, and the Reid report, as an example of finding a way through to the solutions, is going a long way to address those problems that have been created and built up over a number of years.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, the Reid report, released for public comment in May of this year, has gone a long way in bringing to light the inequalities and anti‐competitive behaviour of many players in the marketplace. This has been an ongoing problem. There have been two previous reports acknowledging the concerns of small business that have never seen the light of day. We have to commend the standing committee for their efforts in bringing to light the problems that are existing today.

Finding a Balance is, in effect, the action that needs to be taken to overcome unfair practices and anti‐competitive behaviour as practised by many market traders. For too long small traders and a range of businessmen and women have been operating at a distinct disadvantage in an almost David and Goliath scenario. Unfair trading practices, franchising, retail tenancy and small business finance were the areas addressed as vulnerable to exploitation and abuse. The recommendations came after many months of inquiry from the length and breadth of the Australian marketplace.

After reading the full document, the findings of which have taken nearly 20 years to surface, I found that many of the cases highlighted were strangely familiar. Wherever you go in Australia, small business operators suffer similar consequences due to the lack of a national or uniform body of precedents that could deal with unfair conduct or anti‐competitive behaviour. Action is what is recommended. What action is to be the definitive exercise of the government response? Action in the form of a legislative response is also recommended.

The report recommends that the success of legislative protection will require vigorous enforcement. How this will come about is still in the process of distillation. What are the circumstances that have brought us all to this point? Every elected representative in this House would have an active and working appreciation of how business is conducted in this country. We are all shoppers and purchasers of goods and services. The day‐to‐day situations and circumstances of small business operators are unique when you think that they have to get up each day and face the prospect of either making some income or, in many cases, no income. But they have to put food on the table at night, pay the bills and look hopefully towards the next day of either more of the same or an improvement in their day‐to‐day ritual.

These recommendations, on the whole, address for the first time issues out of the control of the small businessman and businesswoman. This report shows the flaws that have existed for many years in areas such as a tenancy code. The recommendations aim towards the drafting of a uniform tenancy code. This should not be such a hard thing to do, particularly in light of the fact that so many national bodies currently exist whose aims are the best interests of tenants, who are, in effect, small businessmen and businesswomen.

Groups such as the Property Council of Australia, the Australian Retailers Association, the Australian Chamber of Commerce, the Council of Business Organisations of Australia and its constituent bodies, and other retail associations, including the United Retailers Association Incorporated—and there are more—would all benefit from the concept of a uniform retail tenancy code. All retailers around Australia share a common workplace environment. The fact that there is this homogeneity of workplaces quite naturally lends itself to establishing a uniform code of business practice.

In my electorate of Bowman I have at least six major shopping centres, with another in the process of being built. In every one of those you will find stories of hardship caused by the unfair or anti‐competitive behaviour of the landlord or centre manager. One such case occurred recently where a tenant was denied the opportunity to sell his business. The business was turning a good profit but, because of family pressures, he decided to sell up. He found a buyer. The centre manager was happy with the deal. It was a win‐win situation: the seller was happy, the buyer was happy, the centre manager was happy. But, for some strange reason, the landlord was not. He decided the sale would not go ahead because the seller's contract still had 18 months to run. As a result, this man's life has been destroyed. He is in the process of a divorce. His business is suffering, as is his health, and all because of the ridiculous tenancy laws we are currently working under.

Another problem facing tenants is the uncertainty of location. On more than one occasion I have had shopping centre tenants contact me complaining that they have been shifted for no apparent reason. The member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), in tabling this report, alluded to similar problems. He gave the example of small businesses being compulsorily relocated away from the shop for which they had negotiated a lease, with no rights of appeal and no compensation for loss of goodwill.

Take as an example a situation where you are setting up a new store. The shopping centre has just been refurbished and this has included a new major chain store. You decide to take up a position in the vicinity of the major retailer because of the increased traffic flow and potential for increased trade. You put everything you own on the line and spend considerable time and effort in building up a clientele. All of a sudden, the centre manager tells you that your shop is being relocated to another part of the centre. Regardless of the new site, you have lost a huge advantage in that you now have to hope that your customers can find you. Why? Because the manager has done a deal with a new tenant to get them into the centre.

Another area touched on by the report is that of justice for small business. At present, if a small business has a problem, it can be very difficult and often far too costly for them to fight the matter through the courts, particularly when banks are concerned. Banks will invariably win a battle with small business simply because they can continue to pour money into a problem until it goes away. One business I know had a very strong case against a bank; in fact, it was considered that the business would succeed. Unfortunately, the bank was able to prolong the case long enough to wear down the business operator. The bank knew it was at fault but it also knew it would eventually win because it had more resources at its disposal.

If the balance could only be shifted in favour of small business, we would probably see a decrease in the number of cases brought before the courts. Banks and major companies would realise they are required to fight on a level playing field, and would think twice about their actions.

However, we cannot deny that a number of problems facing small business are self‐inflicted. In the mid to late 1980s there was a boom in small businesses. People were encouraged to use their redundancies to start businesses with little or no knowledge of what they were getting into. Those who were not devastated by the Labor induced recession are today just clinging on to their businesses.

Many of these problems could have been avoided with a little forethought and planning. It is another recommendation of this report that improved small business education be provided. It has been suggested that this could be provided through chambers of commerce, trade associations or local and state government bodies. I must acknowledge the good work of the state government in Queensland in assisting small business operators in their business management. I have a very good working relationship with the Office of Business and Industry, and their activities are very helpful in assisting small businesses with their decision making.

After all, a little training can go a long way to create a successful business enterprise; and for every business that fails there is a domino effect on the rest of the economy. If that business has staff, they are out of work, the suppliers to that business lose out due to a decrease in sales, and the customer suffers from a loss of competition.

Mr Deputy Speaker, business people are not looking for handouts. They do not want the government to come along and hand them profits on a plate. In fact, all of the business people I talk to want governments to butt out, to stop interfering and let them get on with business. But to do this they need some sort of level playing field where everyone is equal. I am not talking about the level playing field that Paul Keating was so fond of. I do not believe that exists, at least not at this point in time. What I am referring to is an environment where businesses, both big and small, can coexist in relative harmony; an environment in which they can conduct their business in a competitive yet fair way. I believe the recommendations in this report would achieve this environment, and I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would know, in May this year the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology tabled its long awaited report on fair trading in Australia, Finding a balance . The report, which is a credit to all committee members, was unfortunately overtaken by events.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the report's positive and much needed reform agenda, the recommendations still await a formal response from the Howard government. This government, which at every opportunity proclaims its concern for small business, committed itself to a formal response within three months of the report being tabled. Last week that self‐imposed deadline for a formal response passed but, instead of seeing the formal government response, we saw the new Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) postpone one until the end of this month.

There is no need for further consultations. The committee was made up of members of all parties and, irrespective of their political affiliation, they unanimously recommended a positive legislation reform agenda to protect small business. We all know how badly needed that is.

The thing that endlessly frustrates me is hearing this government parroting the line about bipartisan support on a range of issues. We hear minister after minister—and a few backbenchers too, like the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford)—looking earnestly into the television camera lens saying, `Wouldn't it be great if we had the support of the Australian Labor Party on this issue?' Then they reel off a list of issues that they want bipartisan support on—their much‐vaunted tax reform, native title, the constitutional convention or drugs. Yet, when the support of the Australian Labor Party is announced and committed publicly, as it is on this report and its recommendations, this government does a sprint to hide, and those very same earnest looking ministers and backbenchers baulk at taking action.

Let it be clear: Labor supports each of the recommendations contained in this fair trading report. Since the report was tabled in May, I, along with my Labor party colleagues, have been getting these recommendations around to small business and to the local chambers of commerce in electorates. For my part, I have talked with all of the chambers of commerce in my electorate. I have talked with small business operators, and I have responded to their letters and telephone calls.

A couple of weeks ago, my parliamentary colleague the shadow minister for small business, the honourable Stephen Martin, and I met with small business operators at Shellharbour Square in my electorate—a shopping centre currently undergoing millions of dollars worth of expansion—to discuss this report. I met with representatives of the Motor Traders Association in my office at Albion Park Rail and also with another group in my office here in Canberra, to discuss the report. I have issued media releases indicating my own support and, indeed, the Labor Party's support.

The bipartisan support that the government hungers for is here on this issue—that is, fair trading legislative protection for small business. I cannot understand why this government needs to postpone a formal response to this report and its recommendations until the end of the month. Quite frankly, when Labor was in office, if we had achieved bipartisan support on this issue, we would have grabbed the support with both hands. We certainly would not have called for it endlessly and then, once given it, baulked at the chance to take some action. Let us hear no further excuses.

The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business should forget the postponed deadline and come into the House today and tell small business operators stuck in shopping centres that he knows and understands that they are being treated unfairly and oppressively by big business. The minister should come into the House today and tell small business operators that the big business abuse of their market power is over. He should come into the House today aware that there is unprecedented joint political support for the protection of small operators, through legislation, from unfair conduct. Come into the House today, Minister, and put to rest once and for all the anxious minds of small business operators in shopping centres.

BREAK.PARA: Let the minister come in and tell small business operators that this parliament agrees that big businesses in the form of shopping centres, large retail chains and franchisors have been using their overwhelming market power to squeeze the life from small business. It is somewhat of a fashion for members of the government to come into the chamber and say that they never receive any negative complaints from their constituency about a range of issues and decisions. Small business operators in my electorate have welcomed this report and its recommendations, and they have urged that it be adopted.

The government has the blueprint in this report. The message from small business is: implement the recommendations in full; amend the Trade Practices Act to proscribe unfair conduct; give the ACCC enhanced powers to take action for small business facing unfair trading in the marketplace; draft a national uniform retail tenancy code to be adopted throughout Australia; enact Commonwealth franchising legislation covering all franchise arrangements; include small business in the Australian banking industry ombudsman scheme; improve small business access to legal tribunals for commercial disputes; and improve small business education. The previous speaker spoke about this, and I agree entirely with the comments that she made.

This government has a habit of having to be dragged kicking and screaming to the point of making decisions. This was the case in the response following the Productivity Commission report into the automotive industry. At the end, the strategy Labor promoted was implemented. I suspect that the same situation will apply again to the response to the latest commission report on the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. Labor has promoted this strategy, and the government will implement it. Likewise, Labor has promoted the fair trading report and we support the recommendations.

The Howard government has not come to terms with the task of governing. It is time that the Australian community—and its small business sector—was given some relief from this misery. Again, I congratulate all involved in the compiling of this report. I thought it was an excellent report. I just hope that it will be implemented in full.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). I cannot help but wonder whether he is being slightly disingenuous or rather perverse in indicating his support, and that of the Labor Party, for the recommendations of this report. They were in government for 13 years—
—What about the Beddall report?

—The Beddall report, which I have here, is really the coup de grace for the Labor Party in terms of its support for small business. There is considerable irony in this. The chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology that brought down this report was none other than the deputy chairman of the current committee, David Beddall—hence the Beddall report. I was quite interested in the Beddall report. I came to the parliament in 1990 and the report came down early in 1990. At the time, I had had a considerable amount of experience in small business—in the retail industry in particular. The Beddall report actually brought forward a large number of recommendations, the vast majority of which would have been very advantageous to the small business community.

SPEECH.PARA: But the government of the day, the Labor government, simply did not deal with it. It was not a matter of a month's delay—which the member for Throsby now stands up and complains about. The Labor Party almost totally failed to react to the recommendations that were made by the so‐called Beddall committee. I do not remember how many recommendations there were; there were certainly a large number. As I recall—and I am sure the member from the Labor Party will put me right if I am wrong—most of them were not adopted. Many of them would have been of significant advantage to the small business community.

I do not think that opposition members can come in here and speak with any credibility on the issue of small business. They not only had the Beddall report before them back in 1990 but they also had 13 years in which to address many of the issues which they are now supporting.

To pick up the point the member for Throsby made, a response was promised within three months of the Finding a balance report coming down. A very reasonable rationale was put forward for the slight delay: we had a change of minister in the meantime. To his credit, the new minister wanted to put his own stamp on the report. Obviously, it required a delay of some time to do that. The important thing is that the government's response would be very carefully considered and it would not be, as the honourable member for Throsby is suggesting, some sort of a knee‐jerk response. I do not know whether the opposition's position in the end is that, as the member for Throsby says, `They will accept every recommendation in this report.'

I do not believe that the government can do that. Without wanting to be critical of this very good report, there are obviously some elements of it where I think the hurdle has been set too high for the government. I think the Labor Party, in due course, given the opportunity to reflect carefully upon the report, will realise that that is so. Again, without being too critical of my colleague Bruce Reid who chaired the committee, I need to say—because I have had a lot of involvement in these issues—that there are two distinct sides to the story on most of these issues. I am talking here particularly about some of the matters that are raised early in the report, about retail tenancy matters. We need to give careful consideration to those recommendations.

Before I came to this parliament, and going back many years, my involvement in the retail industry—in particular, the shopping centre industry—gave me a very good understanding. When I first went into shopping centres with retail businesses in the early days of shopping centres, there was a very good relationship between shopping centre owners and the retailers. There was a true partnership. That was the whole basis for the whole regional shopping centre industry in the United States in the first place, and subsequently in Australia. Over the years, for one reason or another, that partnership tended to break down. There was blame on both sides for the breakdown of that particular partnership.

I have no doubt, and I said it before I came to this place and I will say it again here today, that some shopping centre owners were quite rapacious in the sorts of activities that they conducted, and some of those are dealt with in this report. But, by the same token, I can now say—from my position here rather than as a retailer—that I think there are a number of retailers also that did not conduct themselves in a way that brought a great deal of credit to their particular industry.

The name of the report is a very good one. That is really the challenge in this issue, and that is to find a balance which will be in the interests of both sides. The retailers do have a lot to complain about, but I think in the end we need to be very careful that we do not impact strongly on investor confidence—after all, it costs a lot of money. Some of the landlords are small business people themselves. The major ones we are talking about are very substantial Australian businesses. But I think the balance that we need to bring into this argument is to make sure that we do not intrude too much or that we do not overregulate a marketplace that by and large, with some obvious deficiencies, works very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —A massive rip‐off!

—I can understand the member for Throsby in that sense being enamoured with all of these recommendations. Essentially he comes from a party which one would think would be philosophically disposed to regulation. The fact is that the government has a broader interest and a broader responsibility, and that is to ensure that there is a balance in the particular arguments we are having.

SPEECH.PARA: All of the issues that are covered in the report in relation to landlord and retail tenancy matters are important. There are dispute resolutions and security of tenure, and lease assignment has always been a bone of contention. Rents and rent reviews have always been difficult. The payment of outgoings and promotions has always been a difficult issue. Issues relating to tenancy mix have always been bones of contention. None of the things that are covered in this report is new, but essentially they do represent a challenge for the government to find a balance ultimately.

That is why, to answer the member for Throsby's question, we cannot rush into some knee‐jerk response to a report which, after all, is coloured, as any parliamentary report will be, by the sort of input that the committee had. I was not on the committee, but I know, having been on the other side and seen it, that there would have been retailers who came before this committee and told the committee—quite properly and, from their own experience—quite vividly how a landlord had driven them to the point where they had lost their homes or even where there were suicides involved.

But in the end we are dealing with a system in this country based on free enterprise, based on our commitment to allowing markets to work effectively and based on our belief that competition does bring about the best results. That does not mean that we do not give to the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission the sorts of powers that it needs to make sure, particularly in a marketplace like Australia which is small in terms of the population of Australia, that competition is there and there is not a misuse of market power.

Quite clearly in negotiations between landlords and tenants there is the potential for misuse of market power, abuse of market power. A small retailer trying to negotiate with a giant Westfield or a giant Lend Lease or any one of the major shopping centre owners is going to suffer from an imbalance of market power. But that does not necessarily mean that that power is being misused or abused. But ultimately, of course, in any market situation there will be a tendency for that to happen where there is an imbalance in market power.

I think the government has a challenge on its hands in dealing with the recommendations of this report. The Labor Party has the luxury of being in opposition. Obviously the member for Throsby, who listens to his constituents, particularly his retail ones, and some of the retail organisations and small business organisations will be saying, `The solution to all of our problems is to just simply implement this report lock, stock and barrel.' But, Mr Deputy Speaker, I can assure you that the government, if it does its job properly, as I am sure it is doing, will not do that and it will give very careful consideration to the wider implications of that report. For the sake of the small business community, we need to get it right.

Prior to the last election, this government made overtures to the small business community and indicated our belief, philosophically, that we have a strong commitment to the small business community. Many people on our side came from the small business community, so we understand it. We empathise with it. That, of course, contrasts us quite markedly with the Labor Party, where very few of their members actually know very much about how business operates in real terms. But the fact is we created an expectation. When we came into government, I think, in fairness, we found the job of turning this economy round rather more difficult than we expected it might be. But we have done a lot.

The response to this report is only one part of a commitment that this government will demonstrate to small business. Some of the things that we have done, we have spelt out quite clearly. But our priority has to be to create in this country the right climate for strong economic growth, and ultimately, that is what is going to be of benefit not only to small business but also to business more broadly which ultimately will lead to the solution of the biggest problem we have in this country, and that is unemployment. There is no alternative but to go on with the reform started by the Labor Party—I acknowledge that was the case in many respects—to press the pace of reform as strongly as we can in microeconomic reform and tax reform and to press on with our industrial relations reforms, which the member for Throsby foremost in the Labor Party would die in the ditches to prevent. But we need to press on with those reforms if the Australian economy is to move forward. That will be the solution to the problems faced by small business in this country. There are no easy solutions and, in their saner moments, the Labor Party members who have spoken about the government's inactivity, et cetera, know that there are no such things as free lunches—

TALK.START.PARA: —They've had a few in their time!

—They have had a few in their time, as the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) said. But now their time is over, and this government is committed to getting on with the job. Yesterday we put in place another important part of the jigsaw as far as the small business community is concerned. I would like to congratulate the Treasurer for the government's response to the Wallis committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: Actually, the Finding a balance report deals in some detail with the capital requirements of small business. I am not entirely a bank basher, but we all engage in that from time to time. I have no doubt that the small business community has paid heavily for the excesses of the banks through the 1980s and continues to do so. The anecdotal evidence I am getting from the small business community in my electorate, which is doing it really tough because the tourist industry is not as buoyant as it was, is that some of them are still being expected to pay overdraft rates of interest of between 11 and even up to penalty rates of 15 per cent. One of the biggest benefits that we can bring to small business is increased competition in the banking sector. The government's response to the Wallis committee report will ensure that that occurs.

I notice from reading Terry McCrann in today's paper that the Labor Party has apparently indicated by the comments of the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), the shadow treasurer, yesterday that they will support, by and large, the government's response to the Wallis committee report in its implementation. I will quote Terry McCrann on this, because this is the crunch line:

A cautionary note though. Just because Gareth‐Gareth says something certainly does not make it so. If he was able to lead Labor's economic policy from his intellect rather than Kim Beazley's cynical hypocrisy, we would be well on the way to a GST.
(Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 16 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are imported peanuts being withheld from sale; if so, (a) what is the country of origin, (b) will they be returned to the sender and (c) are they being withheld because of heavy metal contamination; if so, what is the (i) contamination and (ii) level of contamination.
(2) How do cadmium levels in the Australian Food Standards Code compare with the European Code.
(3) When was the Australian Standard last altered.
(4) Will the Australian Standard be amended; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Imported peanuts found to be in breach of the requirements of the Food Standards Code (the Code) are withheld from sale.

(a) Peanuts found to be in breach of the Code originate from a wide range of countries. Peanuts that have been in breach for cadmium levels originated from: Argentina; China; India; Malaysia; New Zealand; Philippines; Singapore; USA; Vietnam.

(b) There are a range of options available for imported foods which are in breach of the Code. These include reprocessing to bring the product into compliance, re‐export of the product and destruction of the product. Importers must negotiate the most appropriate option with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. In the case of imported peanuts, where there is no approved method of bringing failed peanuts into compliance they are either re‐exported or destroyed.
(c) Imported peanuts have been found to be in breach of the Code both for aflatoxin contamination and heavy metal contamination.
(i) The heavy metal is cadmium.
(ii) The levels of cadmium found in peanuts that exceed the maximum permitted concentration of 0.05 mg/kg range from 0.06‐0.25 mg/kg.
(2) The European Union has not set levels for cadmium in foods. The Australian Food Standards Code details levels for cadmium in a range of food commodities as follows:

ROW.ENTRY: Foods not containing a food otherwise specified

BREAK.PARA: (3) The peanut entry within the cadmium category has not been altered since it was introduced in 1980. The cadmium category is contained in Standard A12—Metals and Contaminants in Foods. Standard A12 was last altered on 4 April 1996. Entries in the cadmium category of Standard A12 were last altered on 9 March 1994.

(4) There is a proposal currently before the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council (the Ministerial Council responsible for food matters) to amend the cadmium category of Standard A12 as part of the total review of all food standards. In order for the proposal to result in a change to the standard a majority of Health Ministers will need to agree to the recommendation. The statement of reasons provided by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council details the following reasons for the amendment:
In developing the draft variation, the Authority had regard to the following principles:

. The public health principle that contaminant levels in food should be safe and as low as reasonably achievable and that maximum permitted concentrations for food should reflect this principle. This principle is based on the premise that contaminants have no intended function in food and their associated health risks may not yet be fully understood. This approach is consistent with that adopted by the Codex Alimentarius Commission.

. The following additional principles should be applied when establishing Maximum Permitted Concentrations (MPCs) for contaminants. These are secondary to the broader section 10 objectives of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991:
1. An MPC will be established only where it serves an effective risk management function; and MPCs will be set for:

PARA.TAB: (a) all primary commodities (described using Codex food commodity groupings) which provide, or may potentially provide, a significant contribution to the total dietary contaminant intake, as indicated by dietary exposure assessments; and
(b) nominated processed foods where the setting of an MPC for the primary commodity is judged to be ineffective.

BREAK.PARA: 2. An MPC will be set at a level which is consistent with public health and safety as determined by an appropriate risk assessment procedure based on dietary modelling1 and which is reasonably achievable from sound primary production and natural resource management practices. Australian and New Zealand data will normally be used for this purpose.

PARA.TAB: 3. In setting an MPC, consideration will be given to Australia and New Zealand*s international trade obligations under the World Trade Organisation*s Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) agreement and Technical Barrier to Trade (TBT) agreement.

TAB.TAB: In developing the draft variation, the Authority had regard to the following additional matters:

BREAK.PARA: . There is now sufficient information available to identify the major sources of cadmium in the diet. On the basis of all the data available, the total daily intake of cadmium for the average consumer is 9—15 micrograms/day. This is well below the provisional tolerable weekly intake established by the Joint (FAO/WHO) Expert Committee on Food Additives (JECFA) which is equivalent to an intake of 70 micrograms/day. This is the internationally accepted safe level of exposure for cadmium.

. There are a number of measures, other than MPCs, that might be used to reduce contaminant levels in the food supply and consequent dietary intakes. Other measures include improving primary commodity production practices and developing appropriate education programs for population groups with potential for high exposure to particular contaminants.

. The proposed MPCs will control the cadmium levels in the major food commodities and also in those food commodities where there may be potential for cadmium levels to increase if MPCs were not present.
. The revised MPCs will provide realistic and enforceable standards to ensure that cadmium exposure now and in the future is well within internationally accepted safe levels.
The drafting prepared after Full Assessment is amended for the following reasons:

. The reference to `mammalian* after the foods, kidney, liver and meat has been replaced by `cattle, sheep and pig* in order to clearly identify the species to which the MPC applies. Thus, horse and all other species are not subject to this standard. With reference to meat, the word `flesh* has been included in order to be consistent with the definition of meat in Standard C1.

. The reference to `molluscs* has been qualified to exclude dredge/bluff oysters and queen scallops which have naturally‐occurring cadmium levels above 2 mg/kg. These two species do not require a specific MPC as they do not occur in areas where potential contamination could occur, and they contribute only a small amount of cadmium to the total dietary cadmium intake.

. A specific MPC for leafy vegetables has been included in order to continue providing incentive for responsible agricultural management practices which will not lead to an increase in the level of cadmium in these foods.

. The MPC for potatoes has been widened to include other root and tuber vegetables in order to continue providing an incentive for the use of responsible agricultural management practices which will not lead to an increase in the level of cadmium in these foods.

. A specific MPC for rice has been included because rice forms a significant and growing component of the diet and additional data has been provided upon which to establish an MPC for this staple food. The MPC has been established at a level which is consistent with maintaining public health and safety and is the same level as proposed for wheat.

. The proposed new MPCs set safe but more realistic levels for major commodity products including wheat and potatoes. These proposed new MPCs will rectify the current situation in which significant proportions of Australian products are made non‐compliant.
1 Dietary modelling is a technique which combines dietary intake date or model diets with concentration data for food chemicals to estimate dietary exposure to that food chemical.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: War Disability Allowance Recipients: Electoral Division of Barton

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 23 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many ex‐servicemen and women who reside within the electoral division of Barton are in receipt of a war disability allowance.
(2) How many persons referred to in part (1) are totally and permanently incapacitated.
(3) Will ex‐service institutions such as the Lady Davidson Home in Turramurra, become aged care facilities on or after 1 July 1997.
(4) Will entry to an aged care facility on or after 1 July 1997 require payment of a means tested accommodation bond.
(5) Will the family home of an applicant be included in the assets test.
(6) Will war disability allowances be income tested for the first time for the purpose of determining an applicant's eligibility for admission to an aged care facility.
(7) Will other eligibility criteria for ex‐servicemen be laid down from 1 July
1997; if so, what.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 1 214 are in receipt of a disability pension.
(2) 137 are in receipt of a special rate (or totally and permanently incapacitated) pension.

(3) Lady Davidson Hospital is currently owned and operated by the Repatriation Commission for the treatment of veterans. It is not an age care facility but a sub‐acute care hospital. Lady Davidson provides rehabilitation, palliative care and other non‐acute care services.
The Hospital will be sold to Australian Hospital Care, a private operator, with effect from 1 October 1997.

Veterans and war widows in New South Wales will continue to have the choice of treatment at Lady Davidson Hospital under a long term agreement between the Repatriation Commission and Australian Hospital Care.

Under this arrangement Australian Hospital Care will be required to maintain the current services at Lady Davidson, ie rehabilitation, palliative care and other non‐acute care services, at an equivalent or better standard of care than at present.
The future operation of the Hospital by Australian Hospital Care will mean that the services of Lady Davidson Hospital will also be available to the general community.

(4) Entry to an aged care facility may require payment of an accommodation bond if the intending resident can afford to pay one. The bond is not means tested although the resident's minimum assets levels are protected. Where they are required to pay the bond the resident has six months to pay.
The implementation of this measure has been deferred from 1 July 1997 to 1 October 1997. The relevant legislation passed through Parliament on 27th June 1997.

(5) Aged care residents will not be assets tested by the Department of Veterans' Affairs (or Department of Social Security) for the purposes of determining an accommodation bond. The amount of a bond will be negotiated between the aged care facility and the person seeking care. However, there is protection for persons entering care that ensures they are left with at least $22,500 in assets or $45,000 for a couple.
A person's home is not counted as an asset for these purposes if:
. the resident's spouse or dependent child is living in the home; or
. a carer or close relative of the resident has been living in the home for at least five years and the carer or relative is eligible for a pension or benefit payable by DVA or DSS.
This protection continues to apply for as long as the resident remains in aged care even if the spouse, carer or close relative later leaves the home.

(6) and (7) Eligibility for admission to aged care is based only on a person's need for care as assessed by an Aged Care Assessment Team (ACAT). The person's income is not taken into account and is not known by the ACAT.

Income assessment for fees purposes will use the same rules as those applied by DVA (and DSS) in calculating rates of income support pensions. Under the income assessment rules for service pension, disability pension and allowances are not counted as income.
Disability pension is counted as income where a person receives any other form of income support such as age pension payable by DSS or Income Support Supplement paid by DVA.
